abstract: Cost of medical care at University of Utah Health Care has fallen by 0.5 percent annually, in reverse of current trend, attracting attention of other hospital systems; process by which hospital system determines actual costs in order to pare expenses and improve care has been set in place by Dr Vivian Lee; issue acquires more urgency as Affordable Care Act moves toward one-payment system for hospitals.

abstract: Health care providers across United States are increasingly anxious about introduction of more than 100,000 new codes they will be required to use; codes were drawn up according to 10th revision of International Classification of Disease and must be used starting in October; codes could compel doctors to make more in-depth assessments of patients, but providers worry transitioning to new system will lead to some claims and payments being denied or delayed.

headline: 9/11 Recovery Workers: Congress Must Renew Health Programs

abstract: Paula Span The New Old Age column; growing number of physicians who work with the elderly are suggesting benchmarks used to determine chronic kidney disease should be put on age-related scale, acknowledging that all kidney function declines with age; critics say current standards promote preventive measures such as avoidance of certain drugs and diet modifications, which keep further decline at bay.
headline: For Older Adults, Questioning a Diagnosis of Chronic Kidney Disease

abstract: Sarah Lyall reviews book Black Man in a White Coat: A Doctor's Reflections on Race and Medicine by Damon Tweedy.

paragraph: Damon Tweedy’s memoir is at once a painful self-examination and a look at the health implications of being black in a country where blacks are more likely to suffer from certain ailments.

headline: Watchdog: 900,000 Vets May Have Pending Health Care Requests
paragraph: Nearly 900,000 military veterans have officially pending applications for health care from the Department of Veterans Affairs, the department's inspector general said Wednesday, but "serious" problems with enrollment data make it impossible to determine how many veterans were actively seeking VA health care.
text: Watchdog: 900,000 Vets May Have Pending Health Care Requests Nearly 900,000 military veterans have officially pending applications for health care from the Department of Veterans Affairs, the department's inspector general said Wednesday, but "serious" problems with enrollment data make it impossible to determine how many veterans were actively seeking VA health care.

headline: Civilians Pay Heavy Price in Yemen's Taiz, Health Care Collapses: UN
paragraph: Nearly 100 civilians have been killed in the past two weeks in Yemen's southwestern city of Taiz where a collapsing health care service and outbreak of dengue fever are compounding a dire humanitarian situation, the United Nations said on Tuesday.

abstract: Oliver Sacks, British neurologist and acclaimed author who explored mysteries of human brain in best-selling case histories, using his patients' struggles as starting points for stirring reflections on consciousness and human condition, dies at age 82.

paragraph: Dr. Sacks explored some of the brain’s strangest pathways in best-selling case histories like “The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat,” achieving a level of renown rare among scientists.

abstract: Ezekiel J Emanuel Op-Ed article claims price of prescription drugs, which can cost individual several hundred thousand dollars per year, is excessive; argues proposals like using Medicare to negotiate lower prices would drive up costs for those privately insured; proposes United States look to Switzerland and Australia as models for offering effective drugs cheaply, as what concerns patients most is getting good results at reasonable cost.

headline: New York Health Insurer Hacked, Over 10 Million Members Possibly Affected
paragraph: Upstate New York health insurer Excellus BlueCross BlueShield on Wednesday said its computer systems and those at affiliates had been breached, exposing data from more than 10 million members, in the latest case to show the industry is still struggling to ward off hackers.

abstract: Two newly-approved cholesterol-lowering drugs, Praluent and Repatha, may offer solution for patients who fear side effects of commonly prescribed statins; cost of drugs, over $14,000 per year, adds to quandary for doctors, who must consider full impact on patients' lives of lifelong medicines they prescribe (Series: Mending Hearts).

abstract: Editorial expresses concern about very high price of cholesterol drugs Praluent and Repatha, which could outweigh their benefits; notes that both drugs cost about $14,000 per month to take, and most patients prescribed drugs will need to take them for lifetime; underscores necessity for more competition to drive down prices, and for insurers to push pharmaceutical companies for larger discounts.

abstract: United States District Court Judge Richard J Leon rules employers do not need to give insurance coverage for contraception even if their objections are moral rather than religious; case involves group March for Life and turns on key aspect of the Affordable Care Act mandating contraception coverage.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORLOFF, DAVID
paragraph: ORLOFF--Dr. David, died peacefully Sunday of brain cancer. He graduated from St. Albans School 1975, Harvard 1979 and NYU Medical School 1984. He completed his medical training at Yale University and fellowship at the National Institutes of Health. His laboratory work in immunology at the National Institutes of Health was published in Nature. As Director of the Division of Metabolism and Endocrinology Products at the FDA, he oversaw the approval of a new class of statin drugs. After achieving the rank of Captain in the Public Health Service in 2005, he joined Medpace Inc., where he was regarded as an industry opinion leader in the study of metabolic diseases and drug development. David is survived by his mother Dr. Martha Vaughan, sons Nicholas and Jeremy, former wife Dr. Catherine Orentreich, and his siblings, Jonathan, Gregory and Lee. A memorial service will be held at 2:30pm on October 3rd at the Cosmos Club in Washington DC.
text: Paid Notice: Deaths ORLOFF, DAVID ORLOFF--Dr. David, died peacefully Sunday of brain cancer. He graduated from St. Albans School 1975, Harvard 1979 and NYU Medical School 1984. His laboratory work in immunology at the National Institutes of Health was published in Nature. As Director of the Division of Metabolism and Endocrinology Products at the FDA, he oversaw the approval of a new class of statin drugs. After achieving the rank of Captain in the Public Health Service in 2005, he joined Medpace Inc., where he was regarded as an industry opinion leader in the study of metabolic diseases and drug development. David is survived by his mother Dr. Martha Vaughan, sons Nicholas and Jeremy, former wife Dr. Catherine Orentreich, and his siblings, Jonathan, Gregory and Lee. A memorial service will be held at 2:30pm on October 3rd at the Cosmos Club in Washington DC.

headline: NYC Ends Consent Requirement for Circumcision Suction Ritual
paragraph: People who perform an ultra-Orthodox Jewish circumcision suction ritual will no longer have to get parents to sign acknowledgements of potential health risks, the city Board of Health decided Wednesday, reversing a policy that pitted health officials against religious leaders over a practice that dates to biblical times.
text: NYC Ends Consent Requirement for Circumcision Suction Ritual People who perform an ultra-Orthodox Jewish circumcision suction ritual will no longer have to get parents to sign acknowledgements of potential health risks, the city Board of Health decided Wednesday, reversing a policy that pitted health officials against religious leaders over a practice that dates to biblical times.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABLE, ELISSA: THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS
paragraph: SABLE--Elissa: The Board of Directors, residents and staff of RiverSpring Health and the Hebrew Home at Riverdale mourn the loss of our dear friend, Elissa Sable. Elissa, with her beloved husband of blessed memory, Rabbi Jack Sable, was a pillar in the Jewish and Riverdale communities. Elissa's radiance was reflected in her music, her charitable spirit, and most of all, in her devotion to her loving family. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Sable family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Jeffrey Maurer, Chairman, Board of Trustees Daniel Reingold, President and CEO David V. Pomeranz, Chief Operating Officer RiverSpring Health 1/3

headline: Report: $235M Saved by Year Ban on Planned Parenthood Funds
paragraph: A Republican bill that would halt federal payments to Planned Parenthood for a year could reduce health care access for about 390,000 people while saving taxpayers about $235 million, Congress' official authority on the budget said Wednesday.
text: Report: $235M Saved by Year Ban on Planned Parenthood Funds A Republican bill that would halt federal payments to Planned Parenthood for a year could reduce health care access for about 390,000 people while saving taxpayers about $235 million, Congress' official authority on the budget said Wednesday.

headline: New York Smoking Rate Goes Back Down After Startling Rise
paragraph: The ranks of smokers are dwindling after a surprising uptick in a city known for tough steps to discourage tobacco use, health officials said Wednesday.
text: New York Smoking Rate Goes Back Down After Startling Rise The ranks of smokers are dwindling after a surprising uptick in a city known for tough steps to discourage tobacco use, health officials said Wednesday.

headline: Michigan Resident Tests Positive for Plague
paragraph: A Michigan resident is recovering from the state's first ever confirmed case of bubonic plague, state health officials said on Monday.
text: Michigan Resident Tests Positive for Plague A Michigan resident is recovering from the state's first ever confirmed case of bubonic plague, state health officials said on Monday.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, MILTON
paragraph: GILBERT--Milton. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of RiverSpring Health and the Hebrew Home at Riverdale deeply mourn the loss of our esteemed former Chairperson and trustee emeritus, Milton Gilbert. For over 20 years Milton led the Hebrew Home, transitioning it from a highly regarded nursing home into a nationally acclaimed senior care organization. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Elma, Shelley, Fred and the entire Gilbert and Fehrenbach families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Jeffrey Maurer, Chairman, Board of Trustees Daniel Reingold, President and CEO RiverSpring Health 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, MILTON
paragraph: COHN--Milton. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of our former Trustee Milton Cohn. He served our hospitals with enthusiasm and distinction for more than 40 years, first as a Trustee of the former Beth Israel Medical Center, then as a Trustee of Continuum Health Partners and emeritus member of the Board of Overseers of Mount Sinai Beth Israel and Mount Sinai Roosevelt. We will remember his generosity, strong commitment, and wise counsel, and we extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Steven Hochberg, Senior Vice Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

headline: Diesel Fuel Spilled Into Stream on Hilton Head Island
paragraph: Environmental officials are investigating a diesel fuel spill at a marina on Hilton Head Island.
text: Diesel Fuel Spilled Into Stream on Hilton Head Island Environmental officials are investigating a diesel fuel spill at a marina on Hilton Head Island.

headline: Monte Dei Paschi Shareholders Appoint Tononi as New Chairman
paragraph: Shareholders at Italy's Monte dei Paschi di Siena approved on Tuesday the appointment of Massimo Tononi, former head of the Milan stock exchange, as chairman of the bank.
text: Monte Dei Paschi Shareholders Appoint Tononi as New Chairman Shareholders at Italy's Monte dei Paschi di Siena approved on Tuesday the appointment of Massimo Tononi, former head of the Milan stock exchange, as chairman of the bank.

headline: Licenses Suspended at 2 Abortion Clinics in South Carolina
paragraph: South Carolina's public health agency has suspended the licenses of two the state's three abortion clinics and threatened to close them.
text: Licenses Suspended at 2 Abortion Clinics in South Carolina South Carolina's public health agency has suspended the licenses of two the state's three abortion clinics and threatened to close them.

headline: How Much Water Should We Drink Every Day?
paragraph: Readers discuss a doctor’s column debunking the “myth” that we should drink eight glasses a day.
text: How Much Water Should We Drink Every Day? Readers discuss a doctor’s column debunking the “myth” that we should drink eight glasses a day.

headline: FDA Halts Sales of 4 R.J. Reynolds Cigarette Brands
paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday banned sales of four cigarette brands from R.J. Reynolds because they did not meet the agency's safety review requirements.
text: FDA Halts Sales of 4 R.J. Reynolds Cigarette Brands The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday banned sales of four cigarette brands from R.J. Reynolds because they did not meet the agency's safety review requirements.

headline: Second Death Reported in Nationwide Salmonella Outbreak
paragraph: A Texas woman has become the second person to die in a nationwide salmonella outbreak linked to tainted cucumbers sold by a California company, health officials reported Wednesday.
text: Second Death Reported in Nationwide Salmonella Outbreak A Texas woman has become the second person to die in a nationwide salmonella outbreak linked to tainted cucumbers sold by a California company, health officials reported Wednesday.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, PATRICIA S
paragraph: LEVINSON--Patricia S. The Trustees, Faculty, Students, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of our longtime friend Patricia S. Levinson, an extraordinary philanthropist whose commitment to Mount Sinai was deep and abiding. A cherished member of the Boards of Trustees since 1981, Pat brought insights and generosity that touched many areas of the Health System. She was a champion of students, and her personal commitment included the creation of the Robert and Patricia Levinson Student Center, and the endowment of scholarships and fellowships at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. Pat also co-chaired the advisory board of the Center for Multicultural Affairs, was a member of The Mount Sinai Hospital's Auxiliary Board, and supported nursing, social services, and Linkage House, a home for the elderly. Her son, Drew, created the ADS-Dreams Come True Fund, which raises funds for terminally ill children at the Hospital. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Pat's husband, Robert, her children, Margot, John, and Drew, and the entire Levinson family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, PATRICIA S
paragraph: LEVINSON--Patricia S. The board and staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the loss of our long- time board member and vice chairman, an exceptional woman and champion of hospitals, health care innovation and improvement, and voluntarism in New York City. Committed to a vision of patient-centered health care and equal access to the highest quality of care, Pat was unwavering in her support of UHF's mission for more than 20 years. Her wise counsel and candor, strong values, and great energy and focus were complemented by her charm, warmth, and infectious good humor. She has made a lasting imprint on UHF and will be remembered with respect and affection, and greatly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband Bob and her children. J. Barclay Collins II, Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr., President 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, PATRICIA
paragraph: LEVINSON--Patricia. The Board of Trustees, Administration and staff of Blythedale Children's Hospital mourn the passing of our dear friend and former trustee. Pat served on the Board for 40 years in a number of capacities, including Vice President. She was a dedicated advocate for children's health and welfare. She will be missed by all. David Pedowitz, Chair Larry Levine, President & CEO Blythedale Children's Hospital Valhalla, New York 1/3

headline: French Rugby Club Toulon Denies Involvement in Prescription Drug Probe
paragraph: The president of French rugby club Toulon denied on Tuesday that any of his team members were implicated in doping after prosecutors confirmed several pharmacies were under investigation on suspicion of improperly supplying medication.
text: French Rugby Club Toulon Denies Involvement in Prescription Drug Probe The president of French rugby club Toulon denied on Tuesday that any of his team members were implicated in doping after prosecutors confirmed several pharmacies were under investigation on suspicion of improperly supplying medication.

headline: Target, Developing Healthier Habits, Hands Workers Fitbits
paragraph: Target is going on a health kick, aimed at both customers and its employees.
text: Target, Developing Healthier Habits, Hands Workers Fitbits Target is going on a health kick, aimed at both customers and its employees.

headline: US Invites Cuban Workers to Tour Navy Hospital Ship in Haiti
paragraph: The United States is inviting five Cuban medical workers and Cuba's ambassador in Haiti to tour the U.S. Navy hospital ship Comfort while it is docked in Haiti on Friday.
text: US Invites Cuban Workers to Tour Navy Hospital Ship in Haiti The United States is inviting five Cuban medical workers and Cuba's ambassador in Haiti to tour the U.S. Navy hospital ship Comfort while it is docked in Haiti on Friday.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURIE, ABRAHAM
paragraph: LURIE--Abraham, on August 25, 2015 at the age of 97. Beloved husband of the late Nettie, loving father of Susan (Don) and Debra (George). Cherished grandfather of Raphael and Anna. Devoted partner of Anita Gurian. A person of keen intellect, commitment to social change and social justice, Abe was one of the great innovators in social work. His health and mental health program models continue to be used globally. He embodied the best in practice, research, management and program innovation. His work will be carried on by the many people he taught, mentored and inspired and by his writings which number in the hundreds. 1/3
text: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURIE, ABRAHAM LURIE--Abraham, on August 25, 2015 at the age of 97. Beloved husband of the late Nettie, loving father of Susan (Don) and Debra (George). Cherished grandfather of Raphael and Anna. Devoted partner of Anita Gurian. A person of keen intellect, commitment to social change and social justice, Abe was one of the great innovators in social work. His health and mental health program models continue to be used globally. He embodied the best in practice, research, management and program innovation. His work will be carried on by the many people he taught, mentored and inspired and by his writings which number in the hundreds. 1/3

headline: Two Turkish Workers Kidnapped in Baghdad Are Released
paragraph: Two of the 18 Turkish workers kidnapped in Baghdad this month have been released near the southern oil city of Basra, the Turkish ambassador in Baghdad said on Wednesday.
text: Two Turkish Workers Kidnapped in Baghdad Are Released Two of the 18 Turkish workers kidnapped in Baghdad this month have been released near the southern oil city of Basra, the Turkish ambassador in Baghdad said on Wednesday.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, LAWRENCE
paragraph:
PHILLIPS--Lawrence S.

The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of our longtime benefactor Lawrence (Larry) S. Phillips, a great-grandson of Mount Sinai Beth Israel's founder Moses Phillips. Larry was instrumental in the creation of the Phillips Ambulatory Care Center and the Hyman-Newman Institute for Neurology and Neurosurgery, and was a generous supporter of the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing. We are grateful for his deep commitment, insight, and leadership and for steadfastly sustaining the Phillips family's history of philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, David and Laura, and to his entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Steven Hochberg, Senior Vice Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System; Susan Somerville, RN, President, Mount Sinai Beth Israel

paragraph: The international swimming federation has called for virus testing in water which will be used at next year's Olympics, citing health concerns for athletes.
text: Swimming Body Calls for Virus Testing in Rio Olympic Water The international swimming federation has called for virus testing in water which will be used at next year's Olympics, citing health concerns for athletes.

headline: San Diego Firm Recalls Cucumbers After Salmonella Outbreak
paragraph: A California company is recalling its cucumbers after a salmonella outbreak that has sickened 285 people in 27 states and killed a San Diego woman.
text: San Diego Firm Recalls Cucumbers After Salmonella Outbreak A California company is recalling its cucumbers after a salmonella outbreak that has sickened 285 people in 27 states and killed a San Diego woman.

headline: In a 1st, New York to Require Salt Warnings on Eatery Menus
paragraph: Some sub sandwiches, movie theater pretzels and even milkshakes and salads will soon come with a first-of-its-kind salt warning symbol in New York City after officials agreed Wednesday to stake out new ground in a national push for healthier eating habits.
text: In a 1st, New York to Require Salt Warnings on Eatery Menus Some sub sandwiches, movie theater pretzels and even milkshakes and salads will soon come with a first-of-its-kind salt warning symbol in New York City after officials agreed Wednesday to stake out new ground in a national push for healthier eating habits.

headline: New York City to Require Chain Restaurants to Label High-Sodium Food
paragraph: New York City health officials unanimously voted on Wednesday to require chain restaurants to add a warning label to menu items that contain more than the daily recommended amount of sodium, making it the first city in the United States to do so.
text: New York City to Require Chain Restaurants to Label High-Sodium Food New York City health officials unanimously voted on Wednesday to require chain restaurants to add a warning label to menu items that contain more than the daily recommended amount of sodium, making it the first city in the United States to do so.

abstract: Obama administration nominates Duke University-affiliated cardiologist and researcher Dr Robert Califf to be commissioner of Food and Drug Administration; Senate is expected to confirm nomination.
headline: Cardiologist Nominated to Be Head of F.D.A.
paragraph: Dr. Robert Califf, a current deputy commissioner, spent decades at Duke University and is not expected to face serious opposition in his Senate confirmation.
text: Cardiologist Nominated to Be Head of F.D.A. Dr. Robert Califf, a current deputy commissioner, spent decades at Duke University and is not expected to face serious opposition in his Senate confirmation. Obama administration nominates Duke University-affiliated cardiologist and researcher Dr Robert Califf to be commissioner of Food and Drug Administration; Senate is expected to confirm nomination.

headline: Louisiana Officials Try New Path to Block Planned Parenthood
paragraph: Gov. Bobby Jindal's administration is trying a new approach to remove Planned Parenthood from Louisiana's Medicaid program, this time saying it has a reason to block the organization's clinics.
text: Louisiana Officials Try New Path to Block Planned Parenthood Gov. Bobby Jindal's administration is trying a new approach to remove Planned Parenthood from Louisiana's Medicaid program, this time saying it has a reason to block the organization's clinics.

headline: The Latest: Whole Foods: We Didn't Stock Recalled Cucumbers
paragraph: The latest about Louisiana's possible ties to a salmonella outbreak in 27 states (all times local).
text: The Latest: Whole Foods: We Didn't Stock Recalled Cucumbers The latest about Louisiana's possible ties to a salmonella outbreak in 27 states (all times local).

headline: 4th Legionnaires' Disease Death at Illinois Veterans' Home
paragraph: The Illinois Department of Public Health on Monday reported two more deaths from Legionnaires' disease in an outbreak at a western Illinois veterans' home.
text: 4th Legionnaires' Disease Death at Illinois Veterans' Home The Illinois Department of Public Health on Monday reported two more deaths from Legionnaires' disease in an outbreak at a western Illinois veterans' home.

headline: City Hall in Ukraine's Kiev Cancels School Amid Heat Wave
paragraph: The city hall in Ukraine's capital Kiev on Thursday scrapped classes at schools and pre-schools until the end of the week amid a record-breaking heat wave and peat-bog fires.
text: City Hall in Ukraine's Kiev Cancels School Amid Heat Wave The city hall in Ukraine's capital Kiev on Thursday scrapped classes at schools and pre-schools until the end of the week amid a record-breaking heat wave and peat-bog fires.

headline: 3 Louisiana Salmonella Cases May Be in 27-State Outbreak
paragraph: Three cases of salmonella in Louisiana may be part of the outbreak that sickened 285 people in 27 states, killing a 99-year-old California woman, according to the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals.
text: 3 Louisiana Salmonella Cases May Be in 27-State Outbreak Three cases of salmonella in Louisiana may be part of the outbreak that sickened 285 people in 27 states, killing a 99-year-old California woman, according to the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals.

headline: Dana Schuster, Adam Kopald
paragraph: The bride is a reporter at The New York Post. The groom is a lawyer at Goodwin Procter.
text: Dana Schuster, Adam Kopald The bride is a reporter at The New York Post. The groom is a lawyer at Goodwin Procter.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, JULIA
paragraph: WASSERMAN--Julia, a former Connecticut legislator, and local official from Newtown, CT, died on August 18, 2015. Mrs. Wasserman's death concluded a formidable life, from narrowly escaping the Nazi's 1938 Kristallnacht to achieving the highest academic and professional honors in public health and environmental stewardship. Mrs. Wasserman graduated from Sarah Lawrence College, then joined the Women's Army Corps during the Korean War, and served as a captain in the Medical Service Corps. She received her Master's Degree from Columbia University School of Public Health, and remained on their Board until her death. She was predeceased by her husband, Dr. Louis R. Wasserman, a world-renowned hematologist associated with Mt. Sinai Medical Center in New York. Julia Wasserman served on the Newtown Legislative Council and, in 1990 was elected as State Representative from the 106th District from Newtown. Her popularity was such that she rarely had an opponent in the 18 years she served, retiring in 2008. She was then appointed to the Board of Pardons and Paroles by then Gov. M. Jodi Rell, serving until June 30, 2015. Memorial contributions may be made to the Beardsley Zoo, 1875 Noble Ave., Bridgeport, CT 06610. A Celebration of Life will take place at Fairfield Hills, Newtown, CT on Saturday, September 26, 2015 2-5pm 1/3

headline: British Doctor in Northern Yemen Unfazed by 'Crazy Warfare'
paragraph: Windows shattered next to Natalie Roberts as air strikes rained down around a hospital in northwest Yemen, but the British doctor focused only on keeping her war-wounded patients alive while the warplanes circled overhead.
text: British Doctor in Northern Yemen Unfazed by 'Crazy Warfare' Windows shattered next to Natalie Roberts as air strikes rained down around a hospital in northwest Yemen, but the British doctor focused only on keeping her war-wounded patients alive while the warplanes circled overhead.

headline: 2 Cases of Polio Found in Ukraine, Caused by Mutated Virus
paragraph: The World Health Organization says officials have found two children stricken by polio in Ukraine, the country's first cases of the paralytic disease in nine years.
text: 2 Cases of Polio Found in Ukraine, Caused by Mutated Virus The World Health Organization says officials have found two children stricken by polio in Ukraine, the country's first cases of the paralytic disease in nine years.

abstract: Alaskan Gov Bill Walker's order to expand federal Medicaid coverage proceeds after Alaska Supreme Court refuses appeal by State Legislature to halt plan; Republican-controlled Legislature had sought temporary restraining order while filing lawsuit to permanently block expansion.
headline: Alaska: Aided by Governor, Medicaid Coverage Grows
paragraph: Alaska expanded federal Medicaid coverage after the state’s highest court on Monday refused an appeal by the State Legislature to halt Gov. Bill Walker’s expansion order.
text: Alaska: Aided by Governor, Medicaid Coverage Grows Alaska expanded federal Medicaid coverage after the state’s highest court on Monday refused an appeal by the State Legislature to halt Gov. Bill Walker’s expansion order. Alaskan Gov Bill Walker's order to expand federal Medicaid coverage proceeds after Alaska Supreme Court refuses appeal by State Legislature to halt plan; Republican-controlled Legislature had sought temporary restraining order while filing lawsuit to permanently block expansion.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINIG, WILLIAM CHARLES
paragraph: REINIG--William Charles, 91, died on August 25, 2015, in Annapolis, MD. A graduate of Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, Reinig was the leader of the radiation protection program for the first peacetime nuclear reactor at Brookhaven National Laboratory. He subsequently led the research team that performed the preoperational survey of the Savannah River Site near Aiken, SC, the first large-scale assay of naturally occurring radioactivity. He later served as Superintendent of Health Physics and Deputy General Manager at SRS. He was a fellow and President of the Health Physics Society, Chairman of the American Board of Health Physics, and served on the NCRP. He enjoyed gardening, watching movies and reading The New York Times. He maintained an out-of-town subscription to the Times for 64 years. After retirement, he wrote a remarkably detailed memoir about growing up in Queens describing the smallest details of daily life including the daily meals, how Mayor La Guardia read the Sunday comic pages of the New York papers over the radio in the 1930s during a newspaper distribution strike, the presence of a speech teacher at PS 108 who attempted to correct the Brooklyn accents of many of the students, including Bill, and watching Memorial Day parades down Rockaway Blvd led by Civil War Veterans followed by Spanish-American War Vets wearing Teddy Roosevelt hats and World War I Vets marching behind. He greatly enjoyed movies for the simple pleasure of watching, a habit begun in the movie theaters of Queens during the Depression. Bill was a survivor of the 1950 LIRR crash in Rockville Center. In 1949, he married Marion Borgstrom whom he met at Brookhaven. She died in 2007. He is survived by Dr. James Reinig (Ellen) of Annapolis, Dr. Christine Reinig of Santa Fe, NM, and grandchildren Margaret and Ann Reinig and Dennis and Alice Flournoy. 1/3

text: Supplements Don’t Fight Cognitive Decline, N.I.H. Study Says   Often marketed to promote brain health, omega-3 fatty acids and antioxidants failed to outperform a placebo in a test of older adults.

headline: Judge Sides With Interior Secretary in Refuge-Road Dispute
paragraph: A federal judge in Alaska on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit brought over the U.S. Interior Department's refusal to allow for a road through a wildlife refuge to ease medical evacuations.
text: Judge Sides With Interior Secretary in Refuge-Road Dispute A federal judge in Alaska on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit brought over the U.S. Interior Department's refusal to allow for a road through a wildlife refuge to ease medical evacuations.

headline: Abortion, a Personal Choice
paragraph: A doctor writes, “Abortion need not be justified to anyone at any time.”
text: Abortion, a Personal Choice A doctor writes, “Abortion need not be justified to anyone at any time.”

headline: Singapore Schools, F1 Race on Edge as Bad Haze Persists
paragraph: Billowing smoke from Indonesian forest fires has worsened Singapore's air pollution, raising concern among organizers of this weekend's widely anticipated Formula One night race, as well as in schools that reopened Monday after a weeklong term break.
text: Singapore Schools, F1 Race on Edge as Bad Haze Persists Billowing smoke from Indonesian forest fires has worsened Singapore's air pollution, raising concern among organizers of this weekend's widely anticipated Formula One night race, as well as in schools that reopened Monday after a weeklong term break.

headline: Fiat Chrysler, UAW Reach Tentative Contract Deal
paragraph: A tentative contract agreement reached Tuesday between the United Auto Workers and Fiat Chrysler addresses pay and health care issues, but neither side would give specifics about the pact.
text: Fiat Chrysler, UAW Reach Tentative Contract Deal A tentative contract agreement reached Tuesday between the United Auto Workers and Fiat Chrysler addresses pay and health care issues, but neither side would give specifics about the pact.

headline: Scandal-Hit Former Virginia Lawmaker Bows Out of Election Bid
paragraph: A former Virginia Democratic legislator, who won his last election campaigning from a jail cell and reported to the legislative session on work release, gave up his bid for the state Senate on Thursday, citing health concerns.
text: Scandal-Hit Former Virginia Lawmaker Bows Out of Election Bid A former Virginia Democratic legislator, who won his last election campaigning from a jail cell and reported to the legislative session on work release, gave up his bid for the state Senate on Thursday, citing health concerns.

headline: U.S. Government to Extend Healthcare Nondiscrimination Law to Transgender People
paragraph: The U.S. government said on Thursday it will extend its healthcare nondiscrimination law to transgender individuals and require health insurers and medical providers to treat all patients equally, regardless of sex.
text: U.S. Government to Extend Healthcare Nondiscrimination Law to Transgender People The U.S. government said on Thursday it will extend its healthcare nondiscrimination law to transgender individuals and require health insurers and medical providers to treat all patients equally, regardless of sex.

abstract: Dr J Donald Millar, a physician and former public heath official who helped eradicate smallpox on an international scale, dies at age 81.
headline: Dr. J. Donald Millar, 81, Dies; Led C.D.C. Mission That Helped Eradicate Smallpox
paragraph: Dr. Millar oversaw the training, deployment and support of dozens of health workers in some 20 countries in Africa in the 1960s when the disease remained an urgent international health concern.
text: Dr. J. Donald Millar, 81, Dies; Led C.D.C. Mission That Helped Eradicate Smallpox Dr. Millar oversaw the training, deployment and support of dozens of health workers in some 20 countries in Africa in the 1960s when the disease remained an urgent international health concern. Dr J Donald Millar, a physician and former public heath official who helped eradicate smallpox on an international scale, dies at age 81.

abstract: Editorial warns of number of bills in Congress and in states inspired by disingenuous attacks on Planned Parenthood that threaten to curb or end research on fetal tissue; underscores importance of fetal tissue research in producing medical benefits for wide variety of people, including its importance in developing vaccines.
headline: Save Fetal Tissue Research, and Save Lives
paragraph: Banning experimentation on fetal tissue would have a devastating effect on patients, academic researchers and the biotechnology industry.
text: Save Fetal Tissue Research, and Save Lives Banning experimentation on fetal tissue would have a devastating effect on patients, academic researchers and the biotechnology industry. Editorial warns of number of bills in Congress and in states inspired by disingenuous attacks on Planned Parenthood that threaten to curb or end research on fetal tissue; underscores importance of fetal tissue research in producing medical benefits for wide variety of people, including its importance in developing vaccines.

headline: Across Much of US, a Serious Shortage of Psychiatrists
paragraph: It is an irony that troubles health care providers and policymakers nationwide: Even as public awareness of mental illness increases, a shortage of psychiatrists worsens.
text: Across Much of US, a Serious Shortage of Psychiatrists It is an irony that troubles health care providers and policymakers nationwide: Even as public awareness of mental illness increases, a shortage of psychiatrists worsens.

headline: Deadly Sandstorm Engulfs Middle East, Slows Syria Air Strikes
paragraph: A heavy sandstorm swept across parts of the Middle East on Tuesday, killing two people and hospitalizing hundreds in Lebanon and disrupting fighting and air strikes in neighboring Syria.
text: Deadly Sandstorm Engulfs Middle East, Slows Syria Air Strikes A heavy sandstorm swept across parts of the Middle East on Tuesday, killing two people and hospitalizing hundreds in Lebanon and disrupting fighting and air strikes in neighboring Syria.

headline: Dead Squirrel at Lake Tahoe in California Tests Positive for Plague
paragraph: A squirrel found dead at Lake Tahoe last month has tested positive for the plague, health officials said, marking the latest incidence of the disease in California that forced the temporary closure of two Yosemite National Park campgrounds.
text: Dead Squirrel at Lake Tahoe in California Tests Positive for Plague A squirrel found dead at Lake Tahoe last month has tested positive for the plague, health officials said, marking the latest incidence of the disease in California that forced the temporary closure of two Yosemite National Park campgrounds.

headline: China jitters send stocks tumbling again
paragraph: World stocks and commodity prices have tumbled again as poor Chinese data see fears about its economic health make an unwelcome comeback.  As Sonia Legg reports, oil prices also fell more than 3 percent after official data showed China's giant manufacturing sector contracted at the fastest pace in three years.
text: China jitters send stocks tumbling again World stocks and commodity prices have tumbled again as poor Chinese data see fears about its economic health make an unwelcome comeback.  As Sonia Legg reports, oil prices also fell more than 3 percent after official data showed China's giant manufacturing sector contracted at the fastest pace in three years.

text: NYC Firefighters' World Trade Center Memorial Adds 21 Names The Fire Department of New York is adding 21 names to a memorial wall recognizing firefighters who died of illness after being part of the World Trade Center rescue and recovery effort.

headline: FDA Orders Reynolds to Stop Sales of Four Cigarette Brands
paragraph: Reynolds American Inc can no longer sell Camel Crush Bold or three other cigarette products in the United States because they may be more dangerous than similar older cigarettes, the Food and Drug Administration said on Tuesday.
text: FDA Orders Reynolds to Stop Sales of Four Cigarette Brands Reynolds American Inc can no longer sell Camel Crush Bold or three other cigarette products in the United States because they may be more dangerous than similar older cigarettes, the Food and Drug Administration said on Tuesday.

headline: Thai Royal Palace Says King Recovering From Lung Infection
paragraph: Thailand's 87-year-old King Bhumibol Adulyadej is recovering from a high fever and chills but is still being treated for the bacterial infection that caused it, the royal palace says Monday. It was the second announcement in less than a month that the king was suffering from health problems.
text: Thai Royal Palace Says King Recovering From Lung Infection Thailand's 87-year-old King Bhumibol Adulyadej is recovering from a high fever and chills but is still being treated for the bacterial infection that caused it, the royal palace says Monday. It was the second announcement in less than a month that the king was suffering from health problems.

headline: Brother of Post Reporter Detained in Iran Appeals to UN Body
paragraph: The brother of jailed Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian has appealed to a U.N. human rights panel to urge his release from detention in Iran.
text: Brother of Post Reporter Detained in Iran Appeals to UN Body The brother of jailed Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian has appealed to a U.N. human rights panel to urge his release from detention in Iran.

headline: Surgeon General Calls for Steps to Promote Healthy Walking
paragraph: Take a walk: That's the U.S. surgeon general's prescription for sedentary Americans — but communities will have to step up, too, and make neighborhoods easier and safer for foot traffic.
text: Surgeon General Calls for Steps to Promote Healthy Walking Take a walk: That's the U.S. surgeon general's prescription for sedentary Americans — but communities will have to step up, too, and make neighborhoods easier and safer for foot traffic.

headline: U.S. Fast-Food Meat Still Mostly Raised on Antibiotics: Consumer Groups
paragraph: Most large U.S. fast-food chains still serve meat from farm animals that have been routinely fed antibiotics, consumer groups said in a new report, which concluded that many companies have not yet laid out plans to curb the practice.
text: U.S. Fast-Food Meat Still Mostly Raised on Antibiotics: Consumer Groups Most large U.S. fast-food chains still serve meat from farm animals that have been routinely fed antibiotics, consumer groups said in a new report, which concluded that many companies have not yet laid out plans to curb the practice.

text: Christina Chennat,  Ravi Goel On Match.com, they were looking for different partners but found each other.

headline: BMW CEO Faints on Stage at Frankfurt Auto Show
paragraph: German luxury carmaker BMW's new chief executive, Harald Krueger, fainted on stage at the Frankfurt auto show on Tuesday, a Reuters witness reported.
text: BMW CEO Faints on Stage at Frankfurt Auto Show German luxury carmaker BMW's new chief executive, Harald Krueger, fainted on stage at the Frankfurt auto show on Tuesday, a Reuters witness reported.

headline: Cuomo, Top NY Officials Visit Puerto Rico to Tackle Crisis
paragraph: New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo and a delegation of top state officials met with Puerto Rico's governor on Tuesday to develop what he called a historic partnership with the U.S. territory to help it emerge from a deepening economic crisis.
text: Cuomo, Top NY Officials Visit Puerto Rico to Tackle Crisis New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo and a delegation of top state officials met with Puerto Rico's governor on Tuesday to develop what he called a historic partnership with the U.S. territory to help it emerge from a deepening economic crisis.

headline: Judge Sets Hearing on Arkansas Defunding Planned Parenthood

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASNIS, DEBORAH S.
paragraph: ASNIS--Deborah S.,MD, 59, passed away at 11:30am, September 12, 2015 in the presence of her loved ones. Dr. Asnis was Director of Infectious Disease at Flushing Hospital Medical Center and discovered the first US outbreak of West Nile Virus in 1999. Thanks to her quick action, public officials took aggressive precautions against the spread of the virus. On December 8, 2007, she was inducted into the New York City Hall of Fame for Health and Science. Dr. Asnis was also an HIV specialist and prolific clinical researcher, publishing over 35 articles in her career. She was beloved by her residents, nursing staff, and patients. At home, Debbie was devoted to her family. She loved traveling the world with her husband, going to the theater with her children, and being with her mother. She played tennis and piano, delighted in art and culture. Her smile always lit the room. She was committed to education, self-improvement, and the happiness of her loved ones. Dr. Asnis' intelligence was matched with beauty, quick wit, and exquisite fashion sense. She was as kind and concerned for the health of others as she was strong and driven in her own life. She leaves behind a loving husband, Dr. Hal Kazdin, sons Joshua and Matthew, brother Dr. Greg Asnis, and mother Ruth. The world is a poorer place without her. Funeral services will be held at 10am Wednesday at Boulevard- Riverside Chapels and interment at Beth Moses Cemetery. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, PATRICIA S
paragraph: LEVINSON--Patricia S. Known for her summertime straw hat and roll-up-your-sleeves work attitude, Patricia Schulte Levinson died at Mount Sinai Hospital on September 8th after a brief but heroic fight with cancer. She had been active in board work and non-profit affiliations, especially as a Trustee of the Mount Sinai Healthcare System, and was a lifelong New Yorker, a lover of the arts and culture, and who enjoyed spending time with her family and in the summers at her Long Island home. Pat was the daughter of Arthur D. Schulte and Luise Meyer Schulte. She graduated from the Spence School and attended Connecticut College and Columbia University before marrying Robert A. Levinson in 1954. Pat joined the Boards of Trustees of Mount Sinai Hospital in 1981 when she was named President of the Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board, a group she first joined in 1961. Pat served on several of the hospital's board committees both as a member and chair; most recently on the Patient Care and Quality Assurance, Medical Education and Community Relations Committees. Board members grew to anticipate receiving articles and clippings from her, all on recycled paper and all pertinent to the issues of the day. For many years she also served as a Board liaison to the Nursing Department. Pat had been co-chair of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai's Center for Multicultural and Community Affairs (CMCA) Advisory Board since its inception. A champion of students, her personal commitment included the creation of the Robert and Patricia Levinson Student Center, and the endowment of scholarships and fellowships at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. She was a founding member and vice president of New York City's New Alternatives for Children (NAC) where she helped children move from hospitals to loving homes, a director of Linkage House, and vice chair of the United Hospital Fund, as well as a member of Health First's Board of Managers of Senior Health Partners and a former trustee of the Blythedale Children's Hospital. Pat brought friends from all parts of her life to help grow these important causes - whether through raising awareness or opening her home for salon gatherings - always with her famous cheese crackers. She was the recipient of a United Hospital Fund Distinguished Trustee Award for her leadership, guidance, and extraordinary service to Mount Sinai as well as The Jacobi Medallion, awarded by The Mount Sinai Alumni, in recognition of her distinguished service to the Hospital and the School. An involved New Yorker, Pat enjoyed the city in particular ballet, music, theater and all the arts, and made certain that her multitude of friends shared her pleasures. Pat was a devoted wife, mother, aunt, grandmother and friend to many. She was respected for her energy, work ethic and her vast knowledge of the health care issues she worked so diligently to address in her Mount Sinai, NAC and UHF board work. Pat, born in 1933, is survived by her husband of 61 years, Robert A. Levinson, her daughter Margot and two sons, Andrew and John as well as their spouses: John Ganz, Jr, Karen Levinson, and Ronna Levinson. Pat and Bob have five grandsons: Craig, Jamie, Kyle, Jack and Dean. Pat was pre-deceased by her brother Anthony M. Schulte. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to New Alternatives for Children and/or the Patricia Levinson Scholarship Fund, CMCA, at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 24th at 5pm in the Leo C. Stern Auditorium, Annenberg Building, Mount Sinai. Reception to follow. Funeral services will be private. 1/3

abstract: Contract talks continue between United Automobile Workers and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, which was selected by union to be first among Detroit's Big 3 to negotiate new national labor agreement; union seeks to close pay gap between tiers of workers, and possibly limit number of lower-paid employees.
headline: Autoworkers Go to Fiat Chrysler for First Talks
paragraph: The United Automobile Workers is starting with Fiat Chrysler, the least profitable of the three automakers and the one with the most younger workers.
text: Autoworkers Go to Fiat Chrysler for First Talks The United Automobile Workers is starting with Fiat Chrysler, the least profitable of the three automakers and the one with the most younger workers. Contract talks continue between United Automobile Workers and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, which was selected by union to be first among Detroit's Big 3 to negotiate new national labor agreement; union seeks to close pay gap between tiers of workers, and possibly limit number of lower-paid employees.

headline: Detroit Three Show Interest in UAW Healthcare Overhaul Idea
paragraph: The Detroit Three automakers are showing increased interest in the United Auto Workers union's proposal that they pool their healthcare systems, a sign that contract talks between the union and manufacturers are down to the big money issues.
text: Detroit Three Show Interest in UAW Healthcare Overhaul Idea The Detroit Three automakers are showing increased interest in the United Auto Workers union's proposal that they pool their healthcare systems, a sign that contract talks between the union and manufacturers are down to the big money issues.

headline: Mom of Boy Found Dead in Swing Indicted: Manslaughter Charge
paragraph: A Maryland woman who was found pushing her dead son in a playground swing earlier this year has been indicted and charged with manslaughter and child abuse, authorities announced Monday.
text: Mom of Boy Found Dead in Swing Indicted: Manslaughter Charge A Maryland woman who was found pushing her dead son in a playground swing earlier this year has been indicted and charged with manslaughter and child abuse, authorities announced Monday.

headline: Maldives Criticizes UN's Call to Free Jailed Ex-President
paragraph: The Maldives criticized the U.N. human rights chief's call to release the country's imprisoned former president, calling it an effort to circumvent rule of law.
text: Maldives Criticizes UN's Call to Free Jailed Ex-President The Maldives criticized the U.N. human rights chief's call to release the country's imprisoned former president, calling it an effort to circumvent rule of law.

headline: Clinics Seek U.S. Supreme Court Review of Texas Abortion Law
paragraph: Texas abortion providers asked the U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday to hear their challenge to the state's Republican-backed restrictions on abortions that they contend are aimed more at shutting clinics than protecting women's health.
text: Clinics Seek U.S. Supreme Court Review of Texas Abortion Law Texas abortion providers asked the U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday to hear their challenge to the state's Republican-backed restrictions on abortions that they contend are aimed more at shutting clinics than protecting women's health.

headline: Television Dr. Mehmet Oz Returning With 'Heal Thyself' Goal
paragraph: During a self-prescribed listening tour with physicians groups this summer, Mehmet Oz learned just how much it annoyed many doctors when their patients say, "I heard on 'Dr. Oz' ..."
text: Television Dr. Mehmet Oz Returning With 'Heal Thyself' Goal During a self-prescribed listening tour with physicians groups this summer, Mehmet Oz learned just how much it annoyed many doctors when their patients say, "I heard on 'Dr. Oz' ..."

headline: Arizona Corrections: 220 Inmates Ill at Prison's 2 Units
paragraph: Hundreds of inmates at a state prison in northern Arizona have gotten ill in the past 48 hours, and the state Department of Corrections says it's working with health officials to identify the cause.
text: Arizona Corrections: 220 Inmates Ill at Prison's 2 Units Hundreds of inmates at a state prison in northern Arizona have gotten ill in the past 48 hours, and the state Department of Corrections says it's working with health officials to identify the cause.

headline: NY Day Care Worker Who Left Toddlers at Mall Gets Probation
paragraph: A day care worker who left a pair of toddlers at a New York mall while she went home to "teach them a lesson" has been sentenced to probation.
text: NY Day Care Worker Who Left Toddlers at Mall Gets Probation A day care worker who left a pair of toddlers at a New York mall while she went home to "teach them a lesson" has been sentenced to probation.

headline: Death Toll From IS Attack on Yemeni Mosque Rises to 28
paragraph: Yemeni officials say the death toll from an Islamic State-claimed bombing attack at a mosque in the capital has risen to 28.
text: Death Toll From IS Attack on Yemeni Mosque Rises to 28 Yemeni officials say the death toll from an Islamic State-claimed bombing attack at a mosque in the capital has risen to 28.

headline: Thai King Treated for Blood Infection, Lung Inflammation: Palace
paragraph: Thailand's King Bhumibol Adulyadej, the world's longest-reigning monarch, has received treatment for a blood infection and lung inflammation, the palace said on Sunday.
text: Thai King Treated for Blood Infection, Lung Inflammation: Palace Thailand's King Bhumibol Adulyadej, the world's longest-reigning monarch, has received treatment for a blood infection and lung inflammation, the palace said on Sunday.

headline: Actors, Mentally Ill Aid NYC Police Training Meant to Calm
paragraph: A woman called Emily, tears streaming down her face, stood on a ledge threatening to jump. For 15 minutes, a police sergeant used the common thread that connects them — they're both mothers — to gradually talk her out of killing herself.
text: Actors, Mentally Ill Aid NYC Police Training Meant to Calm A woman called Emily, tears streaming down her face, stood on a ledge threatening to jump. For 15 minutes, a police sergeant used the common thread that connects them — they're both mothers — to gradually talk her out of killing herself.

headline: DuPont to Face First Trial Over C-8 Exposure
paragraph: Chemical giant DuPont Monday will face the first trial in litigation from residents near one of its plants in West Virginia who have accused the company of sickening them by emitting a toxic chemical that leaked into their drinking water.
text: DuPont to Face First Trial Over C-8 Exposure Chemical giant DuPont Monday will face the first trial in litigation from residents near one of its plants in West Virginia who have accused the company of sickening them by emitting a toxic chemical that leaked into their drinking water.

headline: Dana Sckolnick, Michael Medovoy
paragraph: The bride is an associate in a law firm, and the groom is an owner of a coffee shop and a restaurant.
text: Dana Sckolnick, Michael Medovoy The bride is an associate in a law firm, and the groom is an owner of a coffee shop and a restaurant.

headline: Alanna Windsor, Bharat Burman
paragraph: The bride is a doctor at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. The groom is a candidate for a medical and a doctoral degree at Tufts.

headline: Crane Operator Blamed for Rhode Island Building Collapse
paragraph: A police report shows that a worker blamed a mistake by a crane operator for the collapse of a building under construction at a private Rhode Island university that injured six people.
text: Crane Operator Blamed for Rhode Island Building Collapse A police report shows that a worker blamed a mistake by a crane operator for the collapse of a building under construction at a private Rhode Island university that injured six people.

headline: Nebraska Nursing Home for Native Americans to Open Next Year
paragraph: A Nebraska nursing home located on the border with South Dakota's Pine Ridge Indian Reservation will begin accepting Native American residents next year to ease a severe care shortage in one of the nation's poorest regions.
text: Nebraska Nursing Home for Native Americans to Open Next Year A Nebraska nursing home located on the border with South Dakota's Pine Ridge Indian Reservation will begin accepting Native American residents next year to ease a severe care shortage in one of the nation's poorest regions.

headline: Fitness Programs Help Campus Rabbis Shape Up
paragraph: As an Orthodox Jew, Rabbi Moshe Gray may not need a cross. But CrossFit? That's another story.

headline: Republicans Lack Votes to Defund Planned Parenthood: McConnell
paragraph: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell undercut threats by fellow Republicans to hold the budget process hostage in an effort to defund Planned Parenthood, saying conservatives do not have enough support in Congress to cut off the group, which is under fire from abortion opponents.
text: Republicans Lack Votes to Defund Planned Parenthood: McConnell Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell undercut threats by fellow Republicans to hold the budget process hostage in an effort to defund Planned Parenthood, saying conservatives do not have enough support in Congress to cut off the group, which is under fire from abortion opponents.

headline: Liberia Back Home for Nations Cup Qualifiers
paragraph: Liberia will host their first full international match since the lifting of an Ebola ban when they play Tunisia in an African Nations Cup qualifier in Monrovia on Saturday.
text: Liberia Back Home for Nations Cup Qualifiers Liberia will host their first full international match since the lifting of an Ebola ban when they play Tunisia in an African Nations Cup qualifier in Monrovia on Saturday.

headline: Mets Have No Plans to Shut Pitcher Matt Harvey Down
paragraph: The New York Mets plan for Matt Harvey to keep pitching as long as they keep playing.
text: Mets Have No Plans to Shut Pitcher Matt Harvey Down The New York Mets plan for Matt Harvey to keep pitching as long as they keep playing.

headline: Gabon Names Opposition Leader, Ruling Party Stalwarts in Reshuffle
paragraph: Gabon reshuffled its cabinet on Friday to bring in a leading critic of President Ali Bongo and an elder statesman from his father's former regime, in what appeared to be a bid to shore up support ahead of elections due next year.
text: Gabon Names Opposition Leader, Ruling Party Stalwarts in Reshuffle Gabon reshuffled its cabinet on Friday to bring in a leading critic of President Ali Bongo and an elder statesman from his father's former regime, in what appeared to be a bid to shore up support ahead of elections due next year.

headline: 10 Mining Sites Where Work Has Halted After Colorado Spill
paragraph: The following mining sites are affected by a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency decision to suspend investigations and some cleanup work at locations with similarities to a mine involved in a 3 million-gallon wastewater spill near Silverton, Colorado, in August:
text: 10 Mining Sites Where Work Has Halted After Colorado Spill The following mining sites are affected by a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency decision to suspend investigations and some cleanup work at locations with similarities to a mine involved in a 3 million-gallon wastewater spill near Silverton, Colorado, in August:

headline: Industry in Final Ad Blitz Against New U.S. Smog Rule
paragraph: A multimedia, multi-state advertising blitz from industry groups opposing new national ozone standards reached Pennsylvania on Tuesday, part of their last-ditch attempt to scuttle the Obama administration's plans to issue new rules governing ground-level smog by Oct. 1.
text: Industry in Final Ad Blitz Against New U.S. Smog Rule A multimedia, multi-state advertising blitz from industry groups opposing new national ozone standards reached Pennsylvania on Tuesday, part of their last-ditch attempt to scuttle the Obama administration's plans to issue new rules governing ground-level smog by Oct. 1.

headline: Planned Parenthood Faces Unexpected Challenge From Obamacare
paragraph: Angered by videos in which Planned Parenthood officials discussed compensation for providing fetal tissue from abortions, Republicans in Congress are again demanding an end to government funding for the nearly 100-year-old provider of women’s health services.
text: Planned Parenthood Faces Unexpected Challenge From Obamacare Angered by videos in which Planned Parenthood officials discussed compensation for providing fetal tissue from abortions, Republicans in Congress are again demanding an end to government funding for the nearly 100-year-old provider of women’s health services.

headline: French Court Confirms Monsanto Liable in Chemical Poisoning Case
paragraph: (This 10 September, 2015 story was refiled to changes the headline, first paragraph to show Monsanto liable, not "guilty", in the civil court ruling)
text: French Court Confirms Monsanto Liable in Chemical Poisoning Case (This 10 September, 2015 story was refiled to changes the headline, first paragraph to show Monsanto liable, not "guilty", in the civil court ruling)

headline: Planned Parenthood Files Suit Over Arkansas Decision to Cut Funding
paragraph: Planned Parenthood filed a lawsuit in federal court on Friday seeking to a block a move by Arkansas Governor Asa Hutchinson that cut state funding for certain programs the reproductive health provider has in the state, the group said.
text: Planned Parenthood Files Suit Over Arkansas Decision to Cut Funding Planned Parenthood filed a lawsuit in federal court on Friday seeking to a block a move by Arkansas Governor Asa Hutchinson that cut state funding for certain programs the reproductive health provider has in the state, the group said.

abstract: The country “faces significant challenges,” but has “made progress on age-friendly policies,” a nongovernmental organization said in a statement.
headline: China Fares ‘Moderately’ in Global Survey on Quality of Life for Older Adults
text: China Fares ‘Moderately’ in Global Survey on Quality of Life for Older Adults   The country “faces significant challenges,” but has “made progress on age-friendly policies,” a nongovernmental organization said in a statement.

headline: Texas Teen Dies After Amoeba Enters Brain
paragraph: A relative says a 14-year-old boy has died after encountering a rare amoeba while swimming in a lake north of Houston.
text: Texas Teen Dies After Amoeba Enters Brain A relative says a 14-year-old boy has died after encountering a rare amoeba while swimming in a lake north of Houston.

headline: Jon Stewart Joins Sept. 11 Medical Care Push: First Responders
paragraph: First responders who were injured or sickened by the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks on New York and Washington said they will visit Congress with comedian Jon Stewart to push lawmakers to extend expiring medical programs as Friday marked 14 years since 9/11.
text: Jon Stewart Joins Sept. 11 Medical Care Push: First Responders First responders who were injured or sickened by the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks on New York and Washington said they will visit Congress with comedian Jon Stewart to push lawmakers to extend expiring medical programs as Friday marked 14 years since 9/11.

abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton has picked up a string of early support from labor unions in recent weeks and on Thursday took her pro-union message to Gov. Scott Walker’s backyard.
headline: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Scott Walker Over Unions at Event in Wisconsin
text: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Scott Walker Over Unions at Event in Wisconsin   Hillary Rodham Clinton has picked up a string of early support from labor unions in recent weeks and on Thursday took her pro-union message to Gov. Scott Walker’s backyard.

headline: Jury Hears Closing Arguments in 13-Year-Old's Murder Trial
paragraph: A prosecutor on Thursday urged a jury in western Michigan to convict a 13-year-old boy of murder in the fatal stabbing of a younger boy at a playground, saying a childhood of neglect and abuse is not a "free pass to kill."
text: Jury Hears Closing Arguments in 13-Year-Old's Murder Trial A prosecutor on Thursday urged a jury in western Michigan to convict a 13-year-old boy of murder in the fatal stabbing of a younger boy at a playground, saying a childhood of neglect and abuse is not a "free pass to kill."

headline: Judge: Man Unfit for Trial in Hedge-Fund Founder Dad's Death
paragraph: A man suspected of killing his hedge-fund founder father over an argument about his allowance is not mentally fit to stand trial and may be sent to a psychiatric facility as early as next week, a judge ruled Thursday.
text: Judge: Man Unfit for Trial in Hedge-Fund Founder Dad's Death A man suspected of killing his hedge-fund founder father over an argument about his allowance is not mentally fit to stand trial and may be sent to a psychiatric facility as early as next week, a judge ruled Thursday.

headline: Obama Honors Arts Luminaries Including Sally Field
paragraph: President Barack Obama honored 21 individuals and organizations on Thursday for works that he says have helped Americans connect and understand each other a little better through the arts and humanities.
text: Obama Honors Arts Luminaries Including Sally Field President Barack Obama honored 21 individuals and organizations on Thursday for works that he says have helped Americans connect and understand each other a little better through the arts and humanities.

headline: Women in Heavy-Drinking South Korea Fuel Demand for Lighter Booze
paragraph: Jeon Seo-jin, 25, finds traditional soju, the clear grain-based liquor popular in South Korea, too strong for her liking.
text: Women in Heavy-Drinking South Korea Fuel Demand for Lighter Booze Jeon Seo-jin, 25, finds traditional soju, the clear grain-based liquor popular in South Korea, too strong for her liking.

headline: French Court Confirms Monsanto Guilty of Chemical Poisoning
paragraph: A French court upheld on Thursday a 2012 ruling in which Monsanto was found guilty of chemical poisoning of a French farmer, who says he suffered neurological problems after inhaling the U.S. company's Lasso weedkiller.
text: French Court Confirms Monsanto Guilty of Chemical Poisoning A French court upheld on Thursday a 2012 ruling in which Monsanto was found guilty of chemical poisoning of a French farmer, who says he suffered neurological problems after inhaling the U.S. company's Lasso weedkiller.

abstract: The Orchestra Now, conceived by Leon Botstein, is intended to serve as something like a medical residency, but for postgraduate musicians.
headline: Bard Training Orchestra Announces First Season
text: Bard Training Orchestra Announces First Season   The Orchestra Now, conceived by Leon Botstein, is intended to serve as something like a medical residency, but for postgraduate musicians.

headline: Wife of Slain Oklahoma Commissioner Seeks Seat Under 'Widow's Clause'
paragraph: The wife of Oklahoma's slain labor commissioner, who was stabbed to death in August, has requested the governor consider her to take over his elected office under a state provision known as the "widow's clause."
text: Wife of Slain Oklahoma Commissioner Seeks Seat Under 'Widow's Clause' The wife of Oklahoma's slain labor commissioner, who was stabbed to death in August, has requested the governor consider her to take over his elected office under a state provision known as the "widow's clause."

headline: Legionnaires' Death Toll Rises to 10 in Western Illinois
paragraph: At least 10 people in western Illinois have now died from Legionnaires' disease, after a state veterans home reported two new fatalities among its residents.
text: Legionnaires' Death Toll Rises to 10 in Western Illinois At least 10 people in western Illinois have now died from Legionnaires' disease, after a state veterans home reported two new fatalities among its residents.

headline: New York Governor Cuomo Pledges Healthcare Help to Puerto Rico
paragraph: Puerto Rico, whose leaders have complained of unequal federal treatment on healthcare, may get some help from the state with the most Puerto Rican citizens outside the island itself - New York.
text: New York Governor Cuomo Pledges Healthcare Help to Puerto Rico Puerto Rico, whose leaders have complained of unequal federal treatment on healthcare, may get some help from the state with the most Puerto Rican citizens outside the island itself - New York.

headline: Cardiff's Millennium to Be Renamed Principality Stadium
paragraph: Cardiff's Millennium Stadium, the home of Welsh rugby which is hosting eight Rugby World Cup games, is to be renamed the Principality Stadium from next year, the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) said on Tuesday.
text: Cardiff's Millennium to Be Renamed Principality Stadium Cardiff's Millennium Stadium, the home of Welsh rugby which is hosting eight Rugby World Cup games, is to be renamed the Principality Stadium from next year, the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) said on Tuesday.

headline: Retail Clinics, Apps Change Doctor-Patient Relationship
paragraph: Tom Coote suspected the stabbing pain in his abdomen was serious, but the harried doctor at the urgent care center suggested it was merely indigestion.
text: Retail Clinics, Apps Change Doctor-Patient Relationship Tom Coote suspected the stabbing pain in his abdomen was serious, but the harried doctor at the urgent care center suggested it was merely indigestion.

headline: NFL's Safety Campaign Includes Rule Changes and PR Effort
paragraph: Jim Gossett has been paid to watch football games for more than 30 years: for three decades as an athletic trainer at Columbia University and four seasons as an injury spotter for the NFL.
text: NFL's Safety Campaign Includes Rule Changes and PR Effort Jim Gossett has been paid to watch football games for more than 30 years: for three decades as an athletic trainer at Columbia University and four seasons as an injury spotter for the NFL.

headline: 3 Earn Prestigious Awards for Studies of Cancer, DNA Damage
paragraph: Three researchers won prestigious medical awards Tuesday for a new approach to treating cancer and insights into how creatures deal with DNA damage.
text: 3 Earn Prestigious Awards for Studies of Cancer, DNA Damage Three researchers won prestigious medical awards Tuesday for a new approach to treating cancer and insights into how creatures deal with DNA damage.

headline: Roche CEO Attacks Britain's 'Stupid' Cancer Drug System
paragraph: Roche Chief Executive Severin Schwan criticised Britain's health system on Tuesday after two of the company's cancer drugs were dropped from use, calling it a "stupid" way to control costs that could jeopardise research in the country.
text: Roche CEO Attacks Britain's 'Stupid' Cancer Drug System Roche Chief Executive Severin Schwan criticised Britain's health system on Tuesday after two of the company's cancer drugs were dropped from use, calling it a "stupid" way to control costs that could jeopardise research in the country.

headline: Unseasonal Sandstorm Sweeps Across Mideast
paragraph: An unseasonal sandstorm swept across the Mideast on Tuesday, blanketing Beirut and Damascus, causing the deaths of at least five people and sending hundreds of others to hospitals with breathing difficulties, officials said.
text: Unseasonal Sandstorm Sweeps Across Mideast An unseasonal sandstorm swept across the Mideast on Tuesday, blanketing Beirut and Damascus, causing the deaths of at least five people and sending hundreds of others to hospitals with breathing difficulties, officials said.

abstract: Norman L Farberow, psychologist whose pioneering efforts studying causes and prevention of suicide helped found suicide prevention center with nation's first 24-hour hot-line, dies at age 97.
headline: Norman L. Farberow Is Dead at 97; Took Study of Suicide to Academic Fore
paragraph: Dr. Farberow was a founder of the nation’s first comprehensive suicide prevention center and helped upend longstanding notions about the nature of suicide.
text: Norman L. Farberow Is Dead at 97; Took Study of Suicide to Academic Fore Dr. Farberow was a founder of the nation’s first comprehensive suicide prevention center and helped upend longstanding notions about the nature of suicide. Norman L Farberow, psychologist whose pioneering efforts studying causes and prevention of suicide helped found suicide prevention center with nation's first 24-hour hot-line, dies at age 97.

headline: Serena's Tall Hurdle in Pursuit of Crowning Achievement
paragraph: Serena Williams developed in the shadow of big sister Venus, who towered over her as a youngster when they grew up together as kids being taught the game by father Richard on the cracked public courts of Compton.
text: Serena's Tall Hurdle in Pursuit of Crowning Achievement Serena Williams developed in the shadow of big sister Venus, who towered over her as a youngster when they grew up together as kids being taught the game by father Richard on the cracked public courts of Compton.

headline: Afghan Surgeon Earns From Rich to Help Pay for Treating Poor
paragraph: Plastic surgeon Abdul Ghafar Ghayur is practicing his own brand of welfare in Afghanistan, where access to healthcare is limited and many cannot afford private treatment.
text: Afghan Surgeon Earns From Rich to Help Pay for Treating Poor Plastic surgeon Abdul Ghafar Ghayur is practicing his own brand of welfare in Afghanistan, where access to healthcare is limited and many cannot afford private treatment.

abstract: Food and Drug Administration orders four types of R J Reynolds cigarettes removed from market, saying company has failed to prove they are not more dangerous than existing cigarette products; 2009 federal law states FDA can reject cigarettes scientists believe present greater health risk than comparable products.
headline: F.D.A. Bans Sales of 4 Cigarette Products by R.J. Reynolds
paragraph: Retailers should stop selling Camel Crush Bold, Pall Mall Deep Set Recessed Filter, Pall Mall Deep Set Recessed Filter Menthol and Vantage Tech 13 products immediately, the agency said.
text: F.D.A. Bans Sales of 4 Cigarette Products by R.J. Reynolds Retailers should stop selling Camel Crush Bold, Pall Mall Deep Set Recessed Filter, Pall Mall Deep Set Recessed Filter Menthol and Vantage Tech 13 products immediately, the agency said. Food and Drug Administration orders four types of R J Reynolds cigarettes removed from market, saying company has failed to prove they are not more dangerous than existing cigarette products; 2009 federal law states FDA can reject cigarettes scientists believe present greater health risk than comparable products.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 7
paragraph: The following tax-exempt, fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
text: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 7 The following tax-exempt, fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.

abstract: Texas abortion providers ask Supreme Court to overrule appeals court decision that would limit state to 10 clinics; say 2013 legislation, which Texas lawmakers claim protect women's health, is costly, gratuitous and disingenuous bid to close clinics; case would give court chance to revise 1992 abortion ruling, which prohibited states' placing excessive restrictions on right to abortion.
headline: Texas Abortion Providers Ask Supreme Court to Reverse Ruling on Clinics
paragraph: Should the Supreme Court agree to hear the case, it could issue its first major abortion ruling since 2007 before its next term ends in June.

headline: 6 San Quentin Inmates Ill With Legionnaires' Disease
paragraph: At least six San Quentin State Prison inmates were ill with Legionnaires' disease and dozens more under observation Sunday, prompting a weekend halt to visitors, no hot meals and limited drinking water supplies at California's oldest prison.
text: 6 San Quentin Inmates Ill With Legionnaires' Disease At least six San Quentin State Prison inmates were ill with Legionnaires' disease and dozens more under observation Sunday, prompting a weekend halt to visitors, no hot meals and limited drinking water supplies at California's oldest prison.

headline: Service Pays Tribute to Slain Television Reporter, Cameraman
paragraph: Community religious leaders gathered Sunday to remember 24-year-old reporter Alison Parker and 27-year-old cameraman Adam Ward, the two television journalists who were shot and killed while working last week.
text: Service Pays Tribute to Slain Television Reporter, Cameraman Community religious leaders gathered Sunday to remember 24-year-old reporter Alison Parker and 27-year-old cameraman Adam Ward, the two television journalists who were shot and killed while working last week.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, CAROL
paragraph: HOPKINS--Carol. Born Ellen Carol Stutz in Chicago, Illinois on December 24, 1927. Died peacefully at her home in Evanston, Illinois on August 28, 2015. Beloved mother of James Dennis Hopkins, Jr. (Laura), Ellen Hopkins Suarez (Mario), Ann Rice (Dale), Paul Hopkins, Matthew Hopkins (Colleen), Martha Sheridan (Leo), and Elizabeth Heltzer (Michael). Treasured grandmother of Katherine Tierney Lester (Jeff), Rebecca Tierney Koepsel (Chris), Hannah Tierney; Jack, Daniel, James and Claire Sheridan; Henry, Rose, George and Estelle Heltzer. Proud great-grandmother of Bridget and Maeve Lester; Emmett and Blythe Koepsel. While raising her children she obtained a Masters Degree in Special Education and taught for twenty three years before retiring as Chair of the OShaughnessy Learning Development Program at Loyola Academy in Wilmette, Illinois. She was committed to learning and family. We are grateful for her faith and her love, and for making us better people. Special thanks to North Shore University Health System Hospice, Joy Cachola, and Angela Manraqui for their compassion and loving care. 1/3
