headline: Braehmer TKOs Konrad in 8th to Keep WBA Light-Heavy Belt
paragraph: Juergen Braehmer defeated fellow German Konni Konrad by an eighth-round technical knockout to retain his WBA light heavyweight title in a one-sided bout on Saturday.
text: Braehmer TKOs Konrad in 8th to Keep WBA Light-Heavy Belt Juergen Braehmer defeated fellow German Konni Konrad by an eighth-round technical knockout to retain his WBA light heavyweight title in a one-sided bout on Saturday.

headline: Connecticut Court Bars Release of Arsenic Killer's Records
paragraph: Records related to the mental hospital incarceration of a serial killer who inspired the play and 1944 movie "Arsenic and Old Lace" don't have to be made public, the state Supreme Court ruled in a decision released Monday.
text: Connecticut Court Bars Release of Arsenic Killer's Records Records related to the mental hospital incarceration of a serial killer who inspired the play and 1944 movie "Arsenic and Old Lace" don't have to be made public, the state Supreme Court ruled in a decision released Monday.

headline: Obama to Award Arts Medals to Sally Field, Stephen King
paragraph: Actress Sally Field and author Stephen King are among luminaries set to receive a National Medal of Arts or a National Humanities Medal from President Barack Obama.
text: Obama to Award Arts Medals to Sally Field, Stephen King Actress Sally Field and author Stephen King are among luminaries set to receive a National Medal of Arts or a National Humanities Medal from President Barack Obama.

abstract: Puerto Rico has become increasingly important to 2016 presidential hopefuls due to growing numbers of voters on mainland and question of commonwealth's statehood; Sen Marco Rubio and Hillary Rodham Clinton plan campaign stops there.
headline: Race Pulls Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton to Puerto Rico
paragraph: The presidential candidates stumped on the same day less than 10 miles apart, highlighting the territory’s increased importance in the nominating process.
text: Race Pulls Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton to Puerto Rico The presidential candidates stumped on the same day less than 10 miles apart, highlighting the territory’s increased importance in the nominating process. Puerto Rico has become increasingly important to 2016 presidential hopefuls due to growing numbers of voters on mainland and question of commonwealth's statehood; Sen Marco Rubio and Hillary Rodham Clinton plan campaign stops there.

abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column highlights study published by researchers at University of Notre Dame that has found correlation between companies that offer large stock option grants as part of executive pay packages and number of serious product recalls at company.
headline: Safety Suffers as Stock Options Propel Executive Pay Packages
paragraph: A study finds a correlation between awarding executives generous stock options and the incidence of product recalls that could affect consumers’ health.
text: Safety Suffers as Stock Options Propel Executive Pay Packages A study finds a correlation between awarding executives generous stock options and the incidence of product recalls that could affect consumers’ health. Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column highlights study published by researchers at University of Notre Dame that has found correlation between companies that offer large stock option grants as part of executive pay packages and number of serious product recalls at company.

headline: California Wildfire to Spew Smoke Through Holiday Weekend
paragraph: A vast and stubborn wildfire that has proven California's biggest this year was expected to spew smoke through the long Labor Day weekend, leaving some campgrounds empty and prompting health warnings.
text: California Wildfire to Spew Smoke Through Holiday Weekend A vast and stubborn wildfire that has proven California's biggest this year was expected to spew smoke through the long Labor Day weekend, leaving some campgrounds empty and prompting health warnings.

headline: Money Does Buy You Happiness, UK Number-Crunchers Say
paragraph: Britons are more likely to rejoice in the health of their bank balance than the size of their house or car, research from the country's statisticians suggested on Friday.
text: Money Does Buy You Happiness, UK Number-Crunchers Say Britons are more likely to rejoice in the health of their bank balance than the size of their house or car, research from the country's statisticians suggested on Friday.

abstract: Report issued by Murphy Institute for Worker Education and Labor Studies at the City University of New York shows unionized black workers in New York City enjoy better pay and benefits than nonunion black workers; data suggests unionization could help blacks across country; nearly 40 percent of city's black workers are unionized, compared with 15 percent in rest of country.
headline: Unionization Important to Closing Racial Wage Gap, Study Says
paragraph: An institute at the City University of New York Graduate Center found that unionized black workers in the city were paid significantly higher than their nonunionized counterparts.
text: Unionization Important to Closing Racial Wage Gap, Study Says An institute at the City University of New York Graduate Center found that unionized black workers in the city were paid significantly higher than their nonunionized counterparts. Report issued by Murphy Institute for Worker Education and Labor Studies at the City University of New York shows unionized black workers in New York City enjoy better pay and benefits than nonunion black workers; data suggests unionization could help blacks across country; nearly 40 percent of city's black workers are unionized, compared with 15 percent in rest of country.

headline: Nearly 41 Percent of Small UK Firms Want to Leave EU-Survey
paragraph: Nearly 41 percent of Britain's small business community want to leave the European Union because they do not believe membership is beneficial for their companies, a survey has shown ahead of a referendum likely next year.
text: Nearly 41 Percent of Small UK Firms Want to Leave EU-Survey Nearly 41 percent of Britain's small business community want to leave the European Union because they do not believe membership is beneficial for their companies, a survey has shown ahead of a referendum likely next year.

headline: Large California Fire Expected to Rage Into Holiday Weekend
paragraph: California's largest wildfire so far this year was expected to rage through the Labor Day weekend in the Sierra Nevada, spewing smoke that has forced campgrounds near a popular lake to close and prompted health warnings, officials said Friday.
text: Large California Fire Expected to Rage Into Holiday Weekend California's largest wildfire so far this year was expected to rage through the Labor Day weekend in the Sierra Nevada, spewing smoke that has forced campgrounds near a popular lake to close and prompted health warnings, officials said Friday.

headline: Veterans' Home Eases Some Restrictions After Deadly Bacteria
paragraph: The scent of chlorine permeates an Illinois veterans' home where nine elderly residents have died from a recent outbreak of Legionnaires' disease. Although a ban on showers has been lifted, hand-written signs still warn against drinking from fountains and stacked cases of bottled water line the hallways.
text: Veterans' Home Eases Some Restrictions After Deadly Bacteria The scent of chlorine permeates an Illinois veterans' home where nine elderly residents have died from a recent outbreak of Legionnaires' disease. Although a ban on showers has been lifted, hand-written signs still warn against drinking from fountains and stacked cases of bottled water line the hallways.

headline: Exclusive: Target Pharmacy Workers Form Union, First in Company's History
paragraph: A group of pharmacy workers within Target Corp's store in Brooklyn, New York, have won a vote to form a microunion, making it the first unionized store at the retailer since its inception in 1902.
text: Exclusive: Target Pharmacy Workers Form Union, First in Company's History A group of pharmacy workers within Target Corp's store in Brooklyn, New York, have won a vote to form a microunion, making it the first unionized store at the retailer since its inception in 1902.

headline: Irish Insurer FBD Boosts Capital via Fairfax Investment
paragraph: Canada's Fairfax Financial Holdings is to invest 70 million euros (51 million pounds) in Ireland's FBD Holdings in the form of a convertible bond to bolster the general insurer's capital, the companies said on Wednesday.
text: Irish Insurer FBD Boosts Capital via Fairfax Investment Canada's Fairfax Financial Holdings is to invest 70 million euros (51 million pounds) in Ireland's FBD Holdings in the form of a convertible bond to bolster the general insurer's capital, the companies said on Wednesday.

headline: New York Police Bust Accused Synthetic Marijuana Drug Ring
paragraph: Law-enforcement agents have arrested 6 people in New York accused of trafficking synthetic marijuana, an illegal drug that has sparked local health fears and led to a spike in hospitalizations and deaths this year, officials said on Wednesday.
text: New York Police Bust Accused Synthetic Marijuana Drug Ring Law-enforcement agents have arrested 6 people in New York accused of trafficking synthetic marijuana, an illegal drug that has sparked local health fears and led to a spike in hospitalizations and deaths this year, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Thai King Recovering After Infection, Lung Inflammation-Palace

headline: Away From Olympics, Sewage Blights Vast Swaths of Rio
paragraph: Rivulets of waste crisscross the labyrinth of alleyways that serve as 5-year-old Kaike de Oliveira Benjamin's playground, forming dark, fetid puddles and gurgling streams of refuse and trash. It's little better inside the tiny, one-room apartment he shares with his mother, two little brothers and infestations of roaches and rats. When it rains, the basement apartment floods ankle-deep with a mixture of rainwater and sewage, and drinking water often comes out of the tap looking and smelling contaminated.

It's little better inside the tiny, one-room apartment he shares with his mother, two little brothers and infestations of roaches and rats. abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: King George VI dies unexpectedly on February 6, 1952, leaving the throne to his daughter Elizabeth.

abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Roberto Suro observes immigration policy, like many contentious election issues, is increasingly determined tacitly by impatient states' defiance of uneven federal efforts; argues piecemeal and often contradictory approaches at state and municipal level could paradoxically evolve into coherent national solution.
headline: Where to Go for Real Immigration Reform
paragraph: States and cities are bypassing congressional paralysis with local solutions that work.
text: Where to Go for Real Immigration Reform States and cities are bypassing congressional paralysis with local solutions that work. Op-Ed article by Prof Roberto Suro observes immigration policy, like many contentious election issues, is increasingly determined tacitly by impatient states' defiance of uneven federal efforts; argues piecemeal and often contradictory approaches at state and municipal level could paradoxically evolve into coherent national solution.

headline: China Finmin Targets Fiscal Policy, Infrastructure to Support Economy
paragraph: China will strengthen fiscal policy, boost infrastructure spending and speed up reform of its tax system to support the  economy, the Ministry of Finance said, joining other steps by authorities to re-energise sputtering growth.
text: China Finmin Targets Fiscal Policy, Infrastructure to Support Economy China will strengthen fiscal policy, boost infrastructure spending and speed up reform of its tax system to support the  economy, the Ministry of Finance said, joining other steps by authorities to re-energise sputtering growth.

headline: Wal-Mart Worker Group Splits in Two; Both Sides Vow to Continue Wage Fight
paragraph: A Wal-Mart Stores Inc worker group that has successfully pushed the retailer to boost wages and improve conditions has splintered over a disagreement about funding and strategic direction, according to people on both sides of the split.
text: Wal-Mart Worker Group Splits in Two; Both Sides Vow to Continue Wage Fight A Wal-Mart Stores Inc worker group that has successfully pushed the retailer to boost wages and improve conditions has splintered over a disagreement about funding and strategic direction, according to people on both sides of the split.

abstract: United Automobile Workers and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles tentatively agree on new contract.

headline: Sides Reach Deal to End 42-Day Bus Strike in Tucson, Arizona
paragraph: The transit bus system in Tucson and a union representing hundreds of workers reached a new contract agreement Wednesday to end a 42-day strike.

headline: Clinton, Rubio Court Puerto Rico Voters as Crisis Looms
paragraph: Puerto Rico's financial crisis loomed over dueling Friday campaign appearances by Democrat Hillary Rodham Clinton and Republican Marco Rubio, two presidential contenders with sharply different positions on a key issue for Puerto Rican voters whose influence is growing in U.S. politics.
text: Clinton, Rubio Court Puerto Rico Voters as Crisis Looms Puerto Rico's financial crisis loomed over dueling Friday campaign appearances by Democrat Hillary Rodham Clinton and Republican Marco Rubio, two presidential contenders with sharply different positions on a key issue for Puerto Rican voters whose influence is growing in U.S. politics.

headline: Amnesty Urges Cameroon to Investigate Abuses in Boko Haram Fight
paragraph: Amnesty International urged Cameroon on Wednesday to investigate the death of 25 prisoners and disappearance of 130 people after raids by security forces, raising concern about possible abuses arising from a crackdown on Islamist Boko Haram militants.
text: Amnesty Urges Cameroon to Investigate Abuses in Boko Haram Fight Amnesty International urged Cameroon on Wednesday to investigate the death of 25 prisoners and disappearance of 130 people after raids by security forces, raising concern about possible abuses arising from a crackdown on Islamist Boko Haram militants.

headline: Funeral Services Held for Michigan Firefighter Hit by Pickup
paragraph: Hundreds of mourners gathered Wednesday in an arena on the Michigan State University campus to honor a firefighter who was killed while collecting money for charity in what authorities say was a deliberate hit-and-run.
text: Funeral Services Held for Michigan Firefighter Hit by Pickup Hundreds of mourners gathered Wednesday in an arena on the Michigan State University campus to honor a firefighter who was killed while collecting money for charity in what authorities say was a deliberate hit-and-run.

headline: US Jobless Rate Falls to 7-Year Low; Fed Move Still Unclear
paragraph: U.S. unemployment fell to a seven-year low of 5.1 percent last month, but hiring slowed — a mixed bag of news that offers few clues to whether the Federal Reserve will raise rock-bottom interest rates later this month.

headline: Hundreds of Latinos Protest at Trump Rally, Clash With Supporters
paragraph: A downtown Dallas rally by presidential hopeful Donald Trump produced some of the sharpest scenes of conflict yet in his campaign as hundreds gathered to protest his positions on immigration and confronted supporters as they left the event.

headline: India Rejects Patent on Pfizer's Arthritis Drug
paragraph: India has again denied Pfizer Inc a patent on its rheumatoid arthritis drug tofacitinib, the latest setback for a multinational drugmaker seeking to enforce its intellectual property rights in the country.

abstract: Study published by Kaiser Permanente, San Francisco's largest private health insurer, in journal Clinical Infectious Diseases finds that not one of 657 clients given pre-exposure prophylaxis became infected with HIV over period of more than two years; subjects were given two-drug combination called Truvada; findings contradict concerns of critics, who said PrEP could lead to more HIV infections.
headline: Insurer Says Clients on Daily Pill Have Stayed H.I.V.-Free
paragraph: The finding contradicts critics’ predictions that pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP, would lead to less condom use and more H.I.V. infections.

text: Hillary Clinton Vows to Confront Sex Assault Issue on Campuses   Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged to take extra steps to end sexual assaults on college campuses, saying during a trip to Iowa that she would try to “ensure a fair process” in such cases and increase support for victims.

headline: Doctors Without Borders: Snakebite Treatment Running Out
paragraph: Doctors Without Borders says the world will run out of one of the most effective treatments for snakebites next year, putting the lives of tens of thousands of people at risk, mostly in developing countries.
text: Doctors Without Borders: Snakebite Treatment Running Out Doctors Without Borders says the world will run out of one of the most effective treatments for snakebites next year, putting the lives of tens of thousands of people at risk, mostly in developing countries.

headline: UAW, Fiat Chrysler Labor Talks Continue as Deadline Looms in U.S
paragraph: Negotiators for Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and the United Auto Workers union continued bargaining Monday evening with hours to go before a 12:01 a.m. EDT (0401 GMT) Tuesday deadline after which the U.S. union could call for a strike.
text: UAW, Fiat Chrysler Labor Talks Continue as Deadline Looms in U.S Negotiators for Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and the United Auto Workers union continued bargaining Monday evening with hours to go before a 12:01 a.m. EDT (0401 GMT) Tuesday deadline after which the U.S. union could call for a strike.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, DORIS J.
paragraph: ALLEN--Doris J.,89, of Tenafly, NJ, passed away September 2. A brilliant, warm and loving wife, mother, grandmother and sister with tremendous wit and wisdom, boundless creativity and exquisite taste. A Madison Avenue pioneer: the first woman director of print traffic at Benton & Bowles. Later at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, she was the pharmacology course administrator and executive editor. Born in Brooklyn, the younger daughter of George Jaffe and Rose Natelson Jaffe. Graduated from Girls Commercial High School, then earned a B.A. in English and speech at Brooklyn College. She credited her drama/speech professor, Joseph H. "Skip" Davidson, with helping her develop the confidence that won her a lifetime of friends and admirers. Member of the Advertising Women of New York and a former president of the American Technion Society's Women's Division, Tenafly chapter. Predeceased by her husband Melvin K. Allen. Survived by daughters Jane E. Allen of Los Angeles and Claudia H. Allen (Philip C. Stahl) of Chicago; beloved grandchildren, Benjamin and Isabel Stahl of Chicago; nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Funeral services 10am Tuesday at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, with burial at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the NYU Joan H. Tisch Center for Women's Health, NYU Office of Development, One Park Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10016. 1/3

headline: Stark Contrasts in Europe's Welcome to Migrants

abstract: Research published in journal Molecular Human Reproduction finds fetal microchimerism is more common than previously thought; fetal microchimerism is process where mothers retain cells from their offspring that are transmitted in utero.

paragraph: The process by which women acquire cells from a fetus, called fetal microchimerism, is not as rare as once thought, but remains quite mysterious.

Research published in journal Molecular Human Reproduction finds fetal microchimerism is more common than previously thought; fetal microchimerism is process where mothers retain cells from their offspring that are transmitted in utero.

headline: Republicans Sorry for Saying Ranger Lied About Making Out

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMEROY, ALOYISE (HASKINS) 95
paragraph: POMEROY--Aloyise (Haskins) 95, a longtime resident of Block Island, RI who wintered in Newport, died July 26, 2015 in the John Clarke Nursing Home in Middletown after a period of failing health. She was the wife of the late Lawrence Pomeroy, a Block Island Times Bayberry Award recipient and public activist on utility and environmental issues. Mrs. Pomeroy was a former member of the board of trustees and a volunteer at Block Island's Island Free Library, the school board and the vestry of St. Anne's by the Sea Episcopal Church. She was a keen birdwatcher and was involved in animal rescue both on Block Island and in Newport. A native of Virginia, Mrs. Pomeroy attended St. Margaret's School of Tappahannock, VA. Mrs. Pomeroy served for many years as assistant to the headmistress of The Brearley School in Manhattan. She is survived by stepsons Lawrence K. Pomeroy (Helen M. Pomeroy) of Manhattan and Block Island; and Joseph B. Pomeroy (companion Mildred Kazeniac) of Westford, MA., as well as numerous cousins in Richmond, VA. Mrs. Pomeroy was the doting step-grandmother of Patrick H. Pomeroy, Peter C. Pomeroy and Lawrence B. Pomeroy, the children of Lawrence K. Pomeroy; and great-grandchildren Pier and Piper Pomeroy, the children of Peter C. Pomeroy. She is also survived by a niece, Nancy Albers of Winston-Salem, NC; nephew Ronald Stephen Haskins of Kernersville, NC; and grand-nephew Matthew Green of Winston-Salem, NC. 1/3

headline: Dutch Journalist Detained for Second Time in Turkey
paragraph: A Dutch journalist said Sunday she was detained by police in a town in Turkey's mainly Kurdish southeast region, where scores of people have died in renewed fighting between security forces and Kurdish rebels.

headline: Refugee Women Give Birth on Way to Europe, Even on Boats
paragraph: The baby names carry the mark of struggle and gratitude.

headline: Crude Oil Prices Fall as Demand Stalls
paragraph: Oil prices dipped on Monday as weakening demand weighed on international markets, although U.S. futures received some support from reduced American drilling.
text: Crude Oil Prices Fall as Demand Stalls Oil prices dipped on Monday as weakening demand weighed on international markets, although U.S. futures received some support from reduced American drilling.

abstract: Hamptons, NY, local Christopher Gangemi observes that many of the summer visitors who shopped in his health food store seemed overly stressed about relaxing; expresses relief that, now that Labor Day is over, they have returned to the city.
headline: The Other Side of the Counter
paragraph: There’s a big difference between people who are relaxed and people who are trying to relax, writes a Hamptons local.
text: The Other Side of the Counter There’s a big difference between people who are relaxed and people who are trying to relax, writes a Hamptons local. Hamptons, NY, local Christopher Gangemi observes that many of the summer visitors who shopped in his health food store seemed overly stressed about relaxing; expresses relief that, now that Labor Day is over, they have returned to the city.

abstract: Boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr defeats Andre Berto in unanimous decision, winning Welterweight world title fight and bringing his record to 49-0; Mayweather reiterates that he is retiring and bout at MGM Grand Garden Arena is his last.
headline: Floyd Mayweather Finishes Bout, and Maybe His Career, With Lopsided Win Over Andre Berto
paragraph: Mayweather’s victory by unanimous decision gave him a record of 49-0, the same as the legendary heavyweight Rocky Marciano.
text: Floyd Mayweather Finishes Bout, and Maybe His Career, With Lopsided Win Over Andre Berto Mayweather’s victory by unanimous decision gave him a record of 49-0, the same as the legendary heavyweight Rocky Marciano. Boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr defeats Andre Berto in unanimous decision, winning Welterweight world title fight and bringing his record to 49-0; Mayweather reiterates that he is retiring and bout at MGM Grand Garden Arena is his last.

headline: Man Gets Jail for Writing Racist Graffiti on Refugees' Homes
paragraph: A New Hampshire man who said he was "angry at an imperfect world" admitted Wednesday he scrawled racist graffiti on the homes of four African refugee families; he was sentenced to a year in jail.
text: Man Gets Jail for Writing Racist Graffiti on Refugees' Homes A New Hampshire man who said he was "angry at an imperfect world" admitted Wednesday he scrawled racist graffiti on the homes of four African refugee families; he was sentenced to a year in jail.

headline: Montana Insists It Can't Release Child Death Information
paragraph: Montana child welfare officials have reiterated their position that state law prohibits disclosure of information about child abuse deaths despite a warning from the federal government that continued secrecy could jeopardize grant money.
text: Montana Insists It Can't Release Child Death Information Montana child welfare officials have reiterated their position that state law prohibits disclosure of information about child abuse deaths despite a warning from the federal government that continued secrecy could jeopardize grant money.

headline: Indian Police Look for Man Blamed for Blast That Killed 90
paragraph: Police in central India were looking Sunday for a man who was being blamed for a massive explosion at a restaurant that killed 90 people, as angry residents protested the way the authorities were handling the case.
text: Indian Police Look for Man Blamed for Blast That Killed 90 Police in central India were looking Sunday for a man who was being blamed for a massive explosion at a restaurant that killed 90 people, as angry residents protested the way the authorities were handling the case.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUNKETT, CARYL D
paragraph: PLUNKETT--Caryl D. Faith, family, friends: These were the cornerstones of the life of Caryl Donnelly Plunkett. A generous and devoted wife, mother, aunt, grandmother and friend to many, Caryl passed away peacefully on September 9th, 2015 surrounded by her family. Caryl was a ray of light and a beacon of strength and energy. She lived each day to its fullest, even as she fought cancer these last ten years. Originally from Plantsville, CT, Caryl graduated from Marymount College in Tarrytown, New York. She returned to Tarrytown soon after graduation when she married William F. Plunkett Jr. and stayed for 48 years to raise their six children. She was an accomplished businesswoman, public servant and active charitable volunteer. She has been honored on several occasions for her accomplishments and good works. Marymount College awarded Caryl both the Gloria Gaines and Golden Dome awards, the highest awards bestowed on alumnae, for her years of service to the College. Caryl was a Dame in the Sovereign Order of Malta and a member of the Patron of the Arts of the Vatican Museum. She served as Chairwoman of the Zoning Board of Appeals of the Village of Tarrytown, a member of the Pregnancy Care Center of Westchester, a volunteer at Maria Fareri Children's Hospital Foundation, and a Board Member of AMIC Clearview School. In 2006, she was appointed by the Governor as Honorary Chair of the New York State Observance of United Nations Day. Always known for her quick wit and generous spirit, she was elegant, fun loving and active. She was a gracious hostess and joyful friend and colleague. More importantly, she selflessly gave her love and humor to all she came into contact with. She was happiest spending time with her family at Bantam Lake, CT or on the beach in Kiawah Island, SC. Caryl, born in 1941, is survived by her husband, Bill, their six children Ryan Plunkett, John Brendan (Jake) Plunkett, Erin Plunkett Niehaus, Kathleen Plunkett O'Connor, Timothy Plunkett, Patrick Plunkett and their spouses, and nineteen grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St Patrick's Cathedral at 1:30pm Monday September 14th. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Caryl Plunkett HOPE in Lung Cancer fund at at Martin Health Foundation, 2135 SE Ocean Blvd., Stuart, FL 34996 or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in honor of Caryl Plunkett. 1/3

abstract: Vocations column; Jenna Miller, genetic counselor for genetic testing company Recombine, discusses her field and her career.
headline: Jenna Miller: Demystifier of Genetic Disorders
paragraph: As a genetic counselor, Jenna Miller helps individuals and couples discover and come to terms with genetic traits that may affect their offspring.

headline: Bills to Regulate Medical Marijuana Head to Gov. Jerry Brown
paragraph: With California voters likely to consider legalizing recreational marijuana use next year, state lawmakers approved a package of legislation that would create the first statewide licensing and operating rules for pot growers and retail weed outlets since the state became the first to legalize medical marijuana in 1996.
text: Bills to Regulate Medical Marijuana Head to Gov. Jerry Brown With California voters likely to consider legalizing recreational marijuana use next year, state lawmakers approved a package of legislation that would create the first statewide licensing and operating rules for pot growers and retail weed outlets since the state became the first to legalize medical marijuana in 1996.

headline: AP Exclusive: After Spill, Work Suspended at 10 Mine Sites
paragraph: Site investigations and some cleanup work at 10 polluted mining complexes in four states were suspended because of conditions similar to those that led to a massive wastewater blowout from an inactive Colorado gold mine, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency officials said.
text: AP Exclusive: After Spill, Work Suspended at 10 Mine Sites Site investigations and some cleanup work at 10 polluted mining complexes in four states were suspended because of conditions similar to those that led to a massive wastewater blowout from an inactive Colorado gold mine, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency officials said.

text: Bayer to List Polymer Business Covestro in 4th Quarter I.P.O. The German drug giant had announced plans last year to spin off the polymer business into a publicly listed entity.

headline: Missouri Mom Charged After Kids Found Living in Crate, Cave
paragraph: A 24-year-old mother is in custody Saturday after her two young children were found barefoot, dirty and living in a wooden shipping crate in an underground cave on the eastern edge of Kansas City, Missouri.
text: Missouri Mom Charged After Kids Found Living in Crate, Cave A 24-year-old mother is in custody Saturday after her two young children were found barefoot, dirty and living in a wooden shipping crate in an underground cave on the eastern edge of Kansas City, Missouri.

headline: Protesters Rally at California Jail After Deputies Arrested
paragraph: Several dozen protesters gathered on Friday outside the California jail where three correctional deputies were accused of beating to death a mentally ill inmate last week, according to news reports and images on social media.
text: Protesters Rally at California Jail After Deputies Arrested Several dozen protesters gathered on Friday outside the California jail where three correctional deputies were accused of beating to death a mentally ill inmate last week, according to news reports and images on social media.

headline: Arson Was Cause of Planned Parenthood Fire in Washington
paragraph: A pre-dawn blaze that heavily damaged a Planned Parenthood clinic was arson, fire investigators in Washington state determined Friday.
text: Arson Was Cause of Planned Parenthood Fire in Washington A pre-dawn blaze that heavily damaged a Planned Parenthood clinic was arson, fire investigators in Washington state determined Friday.

headline: Legionnaires' Outbreaks Not Unusual in Summer & Early Fall
paragraph: Legionnaires' disease has been reported in a handful of states this summer, leading to 19 deaths and more than 100 illnesses. The unrelated cases are part of a typical pattern seen with a disease that tends to appear in warm weather and is mostly dangerous for people who already are sick or weakened.
text: Legionnaires' Outbreaks Not Unusual in Summer & Early Fall Legionnaires' disease has been reported in a handful of states this summer, leading to 19 deaths and more than 100 illnesses. The unrelated cases are part of a typical pattern seen with a disease that tends to appear in warm weather and is mostly dangerous for people who already are sick or weakened.

headline: Rio Games Organizers Vow to Introduce Viral Testing in Waters
paragraph: The International Olympic Committee and Brazilian organizers had repeatedly insisted that only bacterial testing was required despite an analysis showing dangerously high levels of viruses.
text: Rio Games Organizers Vow to Introduce Viral Testing in Waters The International Olympic Committee and Brazilian organizers had repeatedly insisted that only bacterial testing was required despite an analysis showing dangerously high levels of viruses.

headline: Lawmakers Cited for Making Out Pay Fines but Dispute Report
paragraph: The two Minnesota lawmakers cited for allegedly "making out" in a car at a regional park said they paid their fines Friday and would not file a complaint with the Dakota County Sheriff's Office, but stood by their contention that the park ranger's account was wrong.
text: Lawmakers Cited for Making Out Pay Fines but Dispute Report The two Minnesota lawmakers cited for allegedly "making out" in a car at a regional park said they paid their fines Friday and would not file a complaint with the Dakota County Sheriff's Office, but stood by their contention that the park ranger's account was wrong.

headline: FDA Issues Warning Letters to Powdered Caffeine Distributors
paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has issued warning letters to five distributors of pure powdered caffeine, saying the products put consumers at risk.
text: FDA Issues Warning Letters to Powdered Caffeine Distributors The Food and Drug Administration has issued warning letters to five distributors of pure powdered caffeine, saying the products put consumers at risk.

headline: Astana Team Thrown Out of Antidoping Movement
paragraph: The Astana cycling team were thrown out of the Movement for Credible Cycling (MPCC) after the Kazakh outfit failed to comply  with the association's strict anti-doping rules at this year's Tour de France.
text: Astana Team Thrown Out of Antidoping Movement The Astana cycling team were thrown out of the Movement for Credible Cycling (MPCC) after the Kazakh outfit failed to comply  with the association's strict anti-doping rules at this year's Tour de France.

headline: 89 People Killed in Explosions at Central India Restaurant
paragraph: At least 89 people were killed at a restaurant in central India on Saturday when a cooking gas cylinder exploded and triggered a second blast of mine detonators stored illegally nearby, police said.
text: 89 People Killed in Explosions at Central India Restaurant At least 89 people were killed at a restaurant in central India on Saturday when a cooking gas cylinder exploded and triggered a second blast of mine detonators stored illegally nearby, police said.

headline: Mozilla Says Hackers Stole Information From Bugzilla
paragraph: Mozilla, creator of the Firefox web browser, said hackers had stolen security-sensitive information from Bugzilla, its bug tracker, and used it to "attack" Firefox users.
text: Mozilla Says Hackers Stole Information From Bugzilla Mozilla, creator of the Firefox web browser, said hackers had stolen security-sensitive information from Bugzilla, its bug tracker, and used it to "attack" Firefox users.

headline: 2 NYC Jail Guards Charged in Beating of 18-Year-Old Inmate
paragraph: A New York City jail captain and a correction officer have been charged with assault and other crimes in the beating of a mentally challenged 18-year-old inmate in a Rikers Island supply closet last year.
text: 2 NYC Jail Guards Charged in Beating of 18-Year-Old Inmate A New York City jail captain and a correction officer have been charged with assault and other crimes in the beating of a mentally challenged 18-year-old inmate in a Rikers Island supply closet last year.

headline: Timberwolves Coach Saunders Hospitalized in Cancer Treatment
paragraph: Flip Saunders has been hospitalized for testing and treatment following a setback in his fight with cancer, leaving his leadership roles with the Minnesota Timberwolves indefinitely to focus on his health.
text: Timberwolves Coach Saunders Hospitalized in Cancer Treatment Flip Saunders has been hospitalized for testing and treatment following a setback in his fight with cancer, leaving his leadership roles with the Minnesota Timberwolves indefinitely to focus on his health.

abstract: San Francisco’s jails will move toward housing transgender inmates according to their gender identity, the Sheriff’s Department has announced.
headline: A Promising New Policy for Transgender Inmates
text: A Promising New Policy for Transgender Inmates   San Francisco’s jails will move toward housing transgender inmates according to their gender identity, the Sheriff’s Department has announced.

headline: Teen Convicted of Murder in Playground Death of Michigan Boy
paragraph: A jury convicted a 13-year-old boy of first-degree murder Friday, turning aside defense claims that a childhood of abuse should shield him from criminal responsibility for the fatal stabbing of a younger boy at a western Michigan playground.
text: Teen Convicted of Murder in Playground Death of Michigan Boy A jury convicted a 13-year-old boy of first-degree murder Friday, turning aside defense claims that a childhood of abuse should shield him from criminal responsibility for the fatal stabbing of a younger boy at a western Michigan playground.

headline: Planned Parenthood Sues Arkansas Over Loss of Medicaid Money
paragraph: Planned Parenthood filed a federal lawsuit Friday challenging Arkansas' cancellation of its Medicaid provider contract, which Gov. Asa Hutchinson terminated amid concerns about secretly recorded videos released by an anti-abortion group.
text: Planned Parenthood Sues Arkansas Over Loss of Medicaid Money Planned Parenthood filed a federal lawsuit Friday challenging Arkansas' cancellation of its Medicaid provider contract, which Gov. Asa Hutchinson terminated amid concerns about secretly recorded videos released by an anti-abortion group.

headline: Ex-NYU Prof Avoids Prison After U.S. Bribery Case Pared Down
paragraph: A federal judge on Friday sentenced a former medical researcher to no prison time, after he pleaded guilty to a single misdemeanor and not the bribery charges leveled by officials who said a Chinese company paid him for U.S.-funded research information.
text: Ex-NYU Prof Avoids Prison After U.S. Bribery Case Pared Down A federal judge on Friday sentenced a former medical researcher to no prison time, after he pleaded guilty to a single misdemeanor and not the bribery charges leveled by officials who said a Chinese company paid him for U.S.-funded research information.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUNKETT, CARYL
paragraph:
PLUNKETT--Caryl D.

Faith, family, friends: These were the cornerstones of the life of Caryl Donnelly Plunkett. A generous and devoted wife, mother, aunt, grandmother and friend to many, Caryl passed away peacefully on September 9th, 2015 surrounded by her family. Caryl was a ray of light and a beacon of strength and energy. She lived each day to its fullest, even as she fought cancer these last ten years. Originally from Plantsville, CT, Caryl graduated from Marymount College in Tarrytown, New York. She returned to Tarrytown soon after graduation when she married William F. Plunkett Jr. and stayed for 48 years to raise their six children. She was an accomplished businesswoman, public servant and active charitable volunteer. She has been honored on several occasions for her accomplishments and good works. Marymount College awarded Caryl both the Gloria Gaines and Golden Dome awards, the highest awards bestowed on alumnae, for her years of service to the College. Caryl was a Dame in the Sovereign Order of Malta and a member of the Patron of the Arts of the Vatican Museum. She served as Chairwoman of the Zoning Board of Appeals of the Village of Tarrytown, a member of the Pregnancy Care Center of Westchester, a volunteer at Maria Fareri Children's Hospital Foundation, and a Board Member of AMIC Clearview School. In 2006, she was appointed by the Governor as Honorary Chair of the New York State Observance of United Nations Day. Always known for her quick wit and generous spirit, she was elegant, fun loving and active. She was a gracious hostess and joyful friend and colleague. More importantly, she selflessly gave her love and humor to all she came into contact with. She was happiest spending time with her family at Bantam Lake, CT or on the beach in Kiawah Island, SC. Caryl, born in 1941, is survived by her husband, Bill, their six children Ryan Plunkett, John Brendan (Jake) Plunkett, Erin Plunkett Niehaus, Kathleen Plunkett O'Connor, Timothy Plunkett, Patrick Plunkett and their spouses, and nineteen grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St Patrick's Cathedral at 1:30pm Monday September 14th. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Caryl Plunkett HOPE in Lung Cancer fund at at Martin Health Foundation, 2135 SE Ocean Blvd., Stuart, FL 34996 or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in honor of Caryl Plunkett.

headline: Volunteers Recognize Mentally Ill Buried in Unmarked Graves
paragraph: For almost 80 years, no one is thought to have visited Peter Gauslin's grave.
text: Volunteers Recognize Mentally Ill Buried in Unmarked Graves For almost 80 years, no one is thought to have visited Peter Gauslin's grave.

headline: U.S., Cuba Set Agenda on Improving Relations
paragraph: Cuba and the United States on Friday set an agenda for improving relations, putting a priority on more easily attainable agreements while leaving aside difficult issues such as the U.S. trade embargo and naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba said.
text: U.S., Cuba Set Agenda on Improving Relations Cuba and the United States on Friday set an agenda for improving relations, putting a priority on more easily attainable agreements while leaving aside difficult issues such as the U.S. trade embargo and naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba said.

headline: Cincinnati Releases Results of Internal Probe of Fire Death
paragraph: A Cincinnati Fire Department probe of a veteran firefighter's death found that he plunged headfirst into an elevator shaft just after a fellow firefighter wrote a warning on its door in the dark, smoky building, officials said Friday.
text: Cincinnati Releases Results of Internal Probe of Fire Death A Cincinnati Fire Department probe of a veteran firefighter's death found that he plunged headfirst into an elevator shaft just after a fellow firefighter wrote a warning on its door in the dark, smoky building, officials said Friday.

abstract: Food and Drug Administration finalizes rules meant to prevent food-borne illness in United States from contaminated products, including produce; 48 million Americans a year get sick from food-borne diseases and 3,000 die.
headline: U.S. Makes Final an Array of Rules on Food Safety
paragraph: The regulations, which will start to take effect next summer, require food processing companies to reduce risks instead of acting only after someone gets sick.
text: U.S. Makes Final an Array of Rules on Food Safety The regulations, which will start to take effect next summer, require food processing companies to reduce risks instead of acting only after someone gets sick. Food and Drug Administration finalizes rules meant to prevent food-borne illness in United States from contaminated products, including produce; 48 million Americans a year get sick from food-borne diseases and 3,000 die.

abstract: Aid groups and Mexican government have begun programs to link modern medicine and traditional midwifery in effort to reduce mortality among mothers in childbirth; death rates are particularly high in poor regions like Chiapas, where researchers estimate 55 of every 100,000 women in childbirth die.
headline: Training Midwives to Save Expectant Mothers in Chiapas
paragraph: The Mexican state, like many poor areas, has a high death rate among mothers in childbirth. In an effort to change that, village midwives are being linked to modern medicine.
text: Training Midwives to Save Expectant Mothers in Chiapas The Mexican state, like many poor areas, has a high death rate among mothers in childbirth. In an effort to change that, village midwives are being linked to modern medicine. Aid groups and Mexican government have begun programs to link modern medicine and traditional midwifery in effort to reduce mortality among mothers in childbirth; death rates are particularly high in poor regions like Chiapas, where researchers estimate 55 of every 100,000 women in childbirth die.

abstract: Study conducted by National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute suggests people can lower their risk of heart attack and stroke by reducing blood pressure to below 120 rather than current guideline of 140; data will be published in next few months.
headline: Lower Blood Pressure Guidelines Could Be ‘Lifesaving,’ Federal Study Says
paragraph: A new study finds that bringing blood pressure down below current recommendations may greatly reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke.
text: Lower Blood Pressure Guidelines Could Be ‘Lifesaving,’ Federal Study Says A new study finds that bringing blood pressure down below current recommendations may greatly reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke. Study conducted by National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute suggests people can lower their risk of heart attack and stroke by reducing blood pressure to below 120 rather than current guideline of 140; data will be published in next few months.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMEROY, ALOYISE
paragraph:
POMEROY--Aloyise

(Haskins) 95, a longtime resident of Block Island, RI who wintered in Newport, died July 26, 2015 in the John Clarke Nursing Home in Middletown after a period of failing health. She was the wife of the late Lawrence Pomeroy, a Block Island Times Bayberry Award recipient and public activist on utility and environmental issues. Mrs. Pomeroy was a former member of the board of trustees and a volunteer at Block Island's Island Free Library, the school board and the vestry of St. Anne's by the Sea Episcopal Church. She was a keen birdwatcher and was involved in animal rescue both on Block Island and in Newport. A native of Virginia, Mrs. Pomeroy attended St. Margaret's School of Tappahannock, VA. Mrs. Pomeroy served for many years as assistant to the headmistress of The Brearley School in Manhattan. She is survived by stepsons Lawrence K. Pomeroy (Helen M. Pomeroy) of Manhattan and Block Island; and Joseph B. Pomeroy (companion Mildred Kazeniac) of Westford, MA., as well as numerous cousins in Richmond, VA. Mrs. Pomeroy was the doting step-grandmother of Patrick H. Pomeroy, Peter C. Pomeroy and Lawrence B. Pomeroy, the children of Lawrence K. Pomeroy; and great-grandchildren Pier and Piper Pomeroy, the children of Peter C. Pomeroy. She is also survived by a niece, Nancy Albers of Winston-Salem, NC; nephew Ronald Stephen Haskins of Kernersville, NC; and grand-nephew Matthew Green of Winston-Salem, NC.

abstract: National Employment Law Project study finds paychecks for many American workers have diminished since economic recovery started in 2009; drop is biggest for lowest-paid workers in sectors that have had strong hiring.

headline: North Dakota Oil Spill Cleanup Slowed by Lack of Natural Gas

headline: White Supremacist Should Die for Three Kansas Murders, Prosecutor Argues

headline: Study: Pot More a Habit for College Students Than Cigarettes

abstract: New York Gov Andrew Cuomo, concluding daylong tour of Puerto Rico, promises his assistance and advice to help island address its $72 billion in debt; trip to Puerto Rico is latest in several outside of state in Cuomo's second term, after he spent entirety of first term within state's boundaries.

headline: Fukushima-Related Child Cancers Unlikely to Rise-IAEA
paragraph: An increase in thyroid cancer among children is unlikely after the meltdown at Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant four years ago, but it remains unclear exactly how much radiation children in the vicinity of the plant were exposed to, the United Nations' nuclear watchdog said in a report released on Monday.
text: Fukushima-Related Child Cancers Unlikely to Rise-IAEA An increase in thyroid cancer among children is unlikely after the meltdown at Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant four years ago, but it remains unclear exactly how much radiation children in the vicinity of the plant were exposed to, the United Nations' nuclear watchdog said in a report released on Monday.

abstract: Chinese authorities release Guo Yushan, founder of now-closed Transition Institute, after almost year’s detention, along with He Zhengjun, institute's administrative director; men were accused of illegally printing books and other publications, but their detention was likely due to Guo's helping legal activist Chen Guancheng gain asylum in America.
headline: China Releases Guo Yushan, Scholar Who Helped Activist Gain Asylum in U.S.
paragraph: Mr. Guo, who helped Chen Guangcheng leave China in 2012, had been detained for almost a year on charges of illegally producing publications.
text: China Releases Guo Yushan, Scholar Who Helped Activist Gain Asylum in U.S. Mr. Guo, who helped Chen Guangcheng leave China in 2012, had been detained for almost a year on charges of illegally producing publications. Chinese authorities release Guo Yushan, founder of now-closed Transition Institute, after almost year’s detention, along with He Zhengjun, institute's administrative director; men were accused of illegally printing books and other publications, but their detention was likely due to Guo's helping legal activist Chen Guancheng gain asylum in America.

abstract: Political memo; Republican presidential candidates are promising to erase and take back Pres Obama's legacy of actions, but history shows campaign promises sometimes fade when confronted with reality of being president.
headline: Republicans Vow to Erase Obama’s Record, but Such Promises Are Rarely Kept
paragraph: What is condemned during a campaign is often tolerated as soon as a new president settles into the Oval Office.

headline: Volatility Seen Lingering No Matter What the Fed Does
paragraph: While investors, traders and forecasters may be on the fence as to whether the Fed pulls the trigger this week on the first U.S. interest rate hike in nearly a decade, Wall Street's "smart money" is decisive on one thing: market volatility will linger.
text: Volatility Seen Lingering No Matter What the Fed Does While investors, traders and forecasters may be on the fence as to whether the Fed pulls the trigger this week on the first U.S. interest rate hike in nearly a decade, Wall Street's "smart money" is decisive on one thing: market volatility will linger.

headline: Factbox: Benefits Offered to Asylum Seekers in European Countries
paragraph: People seeking refugee status in European countries are generally entitled to food, or money to buy it, plus shelter and medical attention, schooling for their children and access to interpreters and lawyers.
text: Factbox: Benefits Offered to Asylum Seekers in European Countries People seeking refugee status in European countries are generally entitled to food, or money to buy it, plus shelter and medical attention, schooling for their children and access to interpreters and lawyers.

headline: Market Turbulence or Not, North American Investors Plow Into Farm Tech
paragraph: North American investors are pouring money into agriculture technology despite turbulent financial and commodity markets, as cutting-edge advances that enhance farm production bring opportunities for profits.
text: Market Turbulence or Not, North American Investors Plow Into Farm Tech North American investors are pouring money into agriculture technology despite turbulent financial and commodity markets, as cutting-edge advances that enhance farm production bring opportunities for profits.

headline: As Pope Visits, Afro-Cuban Religion Hopes for Recognition
paragraph: The air was choked with smoke from incense and cigars while the faithful sipped sugarcane liquor from a gourd at the altar and spat mist over the crowd.

headline: Nadal Blows 2-Set Slam Lead for 1st Time, Loses to Fognini
paragraph: For the first time in his career, Rafael Nadal lost a Grand Slam match after taking a two-set lead.

headline: Bears Spotted In and Around Denver Searching for Food
paragraph: When a helicopter circled her quiet suburban cul-de-sac early Friday, Carol Rose didn't think it was a manhunt or an air ambulance but instantly knew there must have been another bear sighting in the neighborhood.
text: Bears Spotted In and Around Denver Searching for Food When a helicopter circled her quiet suburban cul-de-sac early Friday, Carol Rose didn't think it was a manhunt or an air ambulance but instantly knew there must have been another bear sighting in the neighborhood.

headline: Interior Dept.: High-Risk Oil, Gas Wells Checks Lack Funding
paragraph: The U.S. Bureau of Land Management lacks sufficient resources to inspect high-risk oil and gas wells on federal land as a drilling boom continues in Wyoming, Colorado and other states, Interior Secretary Sally Jewell said Tuesday.
text: Interior Dept.: High-Risk Oil, Gas Wells Checks Lack Funding The U.S. Bureau of Land Management lacks sufficient resources to inspect high-risk oil and gas wells on federal land as a drilling boom continues in Wyoming, Colorado and other states, Interior Secretary Sally Jewell said Tuesday.

headline: In Bringing Ad-Blocking to Mobiles, Apple Gives Itself a Boost
paragraph: Apple Inc's move to make ad-blocking software available on the iPhone is a double-barrelled effort to boost the health of the so-called app economy, while undermining arch rival Google Inc, which dominates the $120 billion online advertising market.

headline: Experts: Unlikely German Sailor Fell Ill in Rio's Water
paragraph: Medical experts and scientists said Friday it's unlikely that a German sailor with a bacterial skin infection that's resistant to antibiotics contracted the illness in polluted Olympic waters.

headline: Japan Lifts Evacuation Order for Town Near Doomed Nuke Plant
paragraph: Japan's government on Saturday lifted a 4 1/2-year-old evacuation order for the northeastern town of Naraha that had sent all of the town's 7,400 residents away following the disaster at the nearby Fukushima nuclear plant.

headline: Colorado Theater Shooter Held Alone, Closely Watched in Cell
paragraph: Colorado theater shooter James Holmes is being held alone in a cell in a southern Colorado prison, where he is more closely monitored and has fewer privileges than other inmates, officials confirmed.
text: Colorado Theater Shooter Held Alone, Closely Watched in Cell Colorado theater shooter James Holmes is being held alone in a cell in a southern Colorado prison, where he is more closely monitored and has fewer privileges than other inmates, officials confirmed.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIGOTTI, ALBERT F
paragraph: LIGOTTI--Albert F. Beloved husband, father, teacher, and friend, passed away Saturday, September 12, 2015, at the age of 88 years. His life-long love of music is his legacy to those who knew and loved him, and he generously shared that love with his world. Mr. Ligotti was born in Bronx, NY where he lived until 1968 when he moved to Athens, GA with his wife and daughters to begin a teaching career at the University of Georgia's Music Department. An Associate Professor Emeritus of Music, he served on the music faculty for 27 years teaching trumpet and conducting. He was the founder and director of the UGA Wind Ensemble, played in the UGA Faculty Brass Quintet, and served as music director of the Opera/MusicTheatre in association with the UGA Department of Drama and Theatre. Prior to his appointment at UGA, Mr. Ligotti performed as a professional trumpet player for eleven years with the New York Philharmonic under the direction of Leonard Bernstein. He also performed with the Metropolitan Opera Company, the Boston Pops with Arthur Fiedler, as trumpet soloist with the Knickerbocker Chamber Players, the New York City Opera and Ballet companies, the Goldman Band, the Bell Telephone Television Orchestra, the Radio City Music Hall Orchestra, in Broadway show ensembles, and in brass quintets. Mr. Ligotti studied conducting under Michael Fiviesky with coaching from Pierre Monteaux. He held a bachelor's degree from Queen's College and a master's degree from Columbia University. He was active as an adjudicator, clinician, and guest conductor throughout the southeast and arranged and transcribed music, with many works published and professionally recorded. His accomplishments include election to full membership in the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (ASCAP). He was the recipient of the 1999-2000 Bank of America Man of Achievement Award and received the Distinguished Alumni Music Award from Queen's College. As a young man just graduated from Queen's College, he chose to serve his country by enlisting in the United States Coast Guard and was a member of their distinguished Coast Guard Band. The Band developed an international reputation as one of the finest professional concert bands in the world, offering music of great variety and appeal, and he was proud and privileged to be a part of that organization. In the late 1970s, Mr. Ligotti was approached about forming a community orchestra in the Athens, GA area. With the help of the then Office of Cultural Affairs and Jill Read, its director, the plans went ahead, and in the Fall of 1978 the first Board of Directors was selected and the Symphony's charter received from the State of Georgia. In the month of January 1979, the Symphony began rehearsing in the band room of Clarke Central High School and subsequently presented its first concert on April 29, 1979, in Mell Auditorium. Thereafter, under his leadership, grateful musicians who had been given the opportunity to play before family, friends and the community through the Athens Symphony performed consistently before enthusiastic audiences of 2,000 in the Classic Center. Due to health considerations, in 2012 Mr. Ligotti handed over his baton to Susan Dinwiddie, and the Symphony Orchestra, that marvelous gift to the Athens community begun so long ago, continues to this day. Patrons of the Athens Symphony continue to be delighted with the elegant bronze sculpture of Maestro Albert Ligotti produced by Gregory Johnson, Artist. This sculpture can be seen in the lobby of the Classic Center. the Symphony's home since 1996. Mr. Ligotti is survived by his loving wife of 50 years Arlene F. Ligotti, daughter Fran Rothman Prince of Athens, GA, and his brother Raymond Ligotti of Long Island, NY. He was preceded in death by his daughter Jeannie Rothman and his parents Victor and Tilly Ligotti of Athens, GA. Lord & Stephens Funeral Home, Athens, GA, is in charge of services. Friends who wish may make a memorial contribution honoring Maestro Albert F. Ligotti to the Athens Symphony, P.O. Box 5244, Athens, GA 30604. No service is planned at this time. 1/3

abstract: Group of Hispanic lawmakers urge Treasury Sec Jacob J Lew to work with Congress to help Puerto Rico resolve its debts; bills introduced in both houses of Congress would give Puerto Rico power to send some parts of its government into Chapter 9 municipal bankruptcy, but Republican lawmakers have shown little enthusiasm.
headline: Hispanics in Congress Ask Treasury to Prevent ‘Catastrophe’ in Puerto Rico
paragraph: Eight Hispanic lawmakers urged Secretary Jacob J. Lew to intervene on behalf of the financially struggling island as his predecessors helped automakers.
text: Hispanics in Congress Ask Treasury to Prevent ‘Catastrophe’ in Puerto Rico Eight Hispanic lawmakers urged Secretary Jacob J. Lew to intervene on behalf of the financially struggling island as his predecessors helped automakers. Group of Hispanic lawmakers urge Treasury Sec Jacob J Lew to work with Congress to help Puerto Rico resolve its debts; bills introduced in both houses of Congress would give Puerto Rico power to send some parts of its government into Chapter 9 municipal bankruptcy, but Republican lawmakers have shown little enthusiasm.

headline: Report: Massachusetts Agency Failed to Save Boy Now in Coma
paragraph: The Department of Children and Families failed to protect a 7-year-old boy who police say was beaten and starved by his father and who is now in a coma, according to a report released Friday.
text: Report: Massachusetts Agency Failed to Save Boy Now in Coma The Department of Children and Families failed to protect a 7-year-old boy who police say was beaten and starved by his father and who is now in a coma, according to a report released Friday.

headline: Giving to Charity Makes You Happy, Middle Age Is Miserable: Experts
paragraph: Giving to others not only makes us happier but can help lower our blood pressure, while humans are most miserable in their forties for deeply rooted biological reasons, researchers told a conference in London on Thursday.
text: Giving to Charity Makes You Happy, Middle Age Is Miserable: Experts Giving to others not only makes us happier but can help lower our blood pressure, while humans are most miserable in their forties for deeply rooted biological reasons, researchers told a conference in London on Thursday.

headline: Rally Held After Santa Clara County Jail Inmate's Death
paragraph: About 50 people marched Friday in protest at Santa Clara County Main Jail to demand inmates be protected from abuse after an inmate was beaten to death last week under the watch of three deputies now facing possible murder charges.
text: Rally Held After Santa Clara County Jail Inmate's Death About 50 people marched Friday in protest at Santa Clara County Main Jail to demand inmates be protected from abuse after an inmate was beaten to death last week under the watch of three deputies now facing possible murder charges.

headline: Small-Town Pennsylvania Mayor Adds Intrigue to Senate Race
paragraph: With a theme of fighting economic inequality and an outsize reputation for unconventional methods, the tattooed mayor of a small hardscrabble steel town near Pittsburgh said Monday that he will join Pennsylvania's competitive and expensive race for U.S. Senate.
text: Small-Town Pennsylvania Mayor Adds Intrigue to Senate Race With a theme of fighting economic inequality and an outsize reputation for unconventional methods, the tattooed mayor of a small hardscrabble steel town near Pittsburgh said Monday that he will join Pennsylvania's competitive and expensive race for U.S. Senate.

headline: Krysta Rodriguez Won't Let Cancer Slow Her Broadway Return

headline: 'Deflategate' Unlikely to Harm NFL Brand, Experts Say
paragraph: The National Football League has managed to flourish through a number of highly-publicized fiascoes in recent years and sports experts expect more of the same despite a months-long battle with its most popular player.
text: 'Deflategate' Unlikely to Harm NFL Brand, Experts Say The National Football League has managed to flourish through a number of highly-publicized fiascoes in recent years and sports experts expect more of the same despite a months-long battle with its most popular player.

headline: America's City Rankings Set for Texas-Sized Shake Up; Houston to Edge Past Chicago
paragraph: Hidden in the haze of the petrochemical plants and beyond the seemingly endless traffic jams, a Texas city has grown so large that it is poised to pass Chicago as the third biggest in the United States in the next decade.
text: America's City Rankings Set for Texas-Sized Shake Up; Houston to Edge Past Chicago Hidden in the haze of the petrochemical plants and beyond the seemingly endless traffic jams, a Texas city has grown so large that it is poised to pass Chicago as the third biggest in the United States in the next decade.

headline: China Grabs Unused Funds to Spend on New Projects as Growth Slows
paragraph: Chinese authorities have seized up to 1 trillion yuan ($157 billion) from local governments who failed to use their budget allocations, sources said, as Beijing looks for ways to spend its way out of an economic slowdown.
text: China Grabs Unused Funds to Spend on New Projects as Growth Slows Chinese authorities have seized up to 1 trillion yuan ($157 billion) from local governments who failed to use their budget allocations, sources said, as Beijing looks for ways to spend its way out of an economic slowdown.

headline: 3 California Deputies Arrested; Inmate Died of Blunt Trauma
paragraph: Three Northern California jail guards have been arrested after an inmate under their watch was found dead of multiple blunt trauma, authorities said Thursday.
text: 3 California Deputies Arrested; Inmate Died of Blunt Trauma Three Northern California jail guards have been arrested after an inmate under their watch was found dead of multiple blunt trauma, authorities said Thursday.

abstract: New York Mets defeat Atlanta Braves, 10-7, in 10 innings.
headline: The New Mets: They Finish a Sweep, Then Grumble About Their Miscues
paragraph: The Mets scored three runs on a two-out ninth-inning home run to tie the game and then scored three more times in the 10th inning to complete a four-game sweep in Atlanta.
text: The New Mets: They Finish a Sweep, Then Grumble About Their Miscues The Mets scored three runs on a two-out ninth-inning home run to tie the game and then scored three more times in the 10th inning to complete a four-game sweep in Atlanta. New York Mets defeat Atlanta Braves, 10-7, in 10 innings.

headline: Mayweather's Legacy Still Up for Debate
paragraph: Should Floyd Mayweather's boxing career now be over, as the undefeated American insisted after easily beating Andre Berto in their welterweight showdown on Saturday, his place among the sport's very best is assured.
text: Mayweather's Legacy Still Up for Debate Should Floyd Mayweather's boxing career now be over, as the undefeated American insisted after easily beating Andre Berto in their welterweight showdown on Saturday, his place among the sport's very best is assured.

headline: Give Money May His Due After a Perfect 19 Years in the Ring

headline: Desert Tribe Faces Hardship as Venezuela Fights Smuggling
paragraph: Less than two days after Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro closed this lonely border outpost on the northern tip of South America, the eight-member Apochana family emerged from the dusty scrubland and shuffled up to a group of Colombian soldiers. The travelers were dripping sweat but dressed impeccably in black-and-white linen robes to attend a relative's funeral on the other side of the border.

The travelers were dripping sweat but dressed impeccably in black-and-white linen robes to attend a relative's funeral on the other side of the border.

headline: Puerto Rico Unveils Fiscal Reform Plan, Braces for Cuts
paragraph: Puerto Rico is bracing for widespread spending cuts after the government released a long-awaited fiscal reform plan on Wednesday that would reduce much of the island's $72 billion public debt and calls for restructuring the remainder at the expense of bondholders.
text: Puerto Rico Unveils Fiscal Reform Plan, Braces for Cuts Puerto Rico is bracing for widespread spending cuts after the government released a long-awaited fiscal reform plan on Wednesday that would reduce much of the island's $72 billion public debt and calls for restructuring the remainder at the expense of bondholders.

abstract: Emails leaked by hackers reveal Sony Picture Entertainment changed script and marketing of movie Concussion, which focuses on NFL's attempts to cover up lasting damage concussions have on football players, in order to avoid angering league; revelation, remarkable given studio does not have significant ties to league, underscores controversy surrounding subject of concussions.
headline: Sony Altered ‘Concussion’ Film to Prevent N.F.L. Protests, Emails Show

abstract: Joe Nocera Op-Ed column posits Brazil is more likely than other BRICS nations to overcome sluggish economic growth because its democracy and judicial institutions are intact and operational; suggests even though corruption is endemic in country and economy is in recession, Brazilian people are still able to chart their own course going forward.

headline: Timber Business Booming Throughout Northeast Florida
paragraph: The towering grove of century-old longleaf pines surrounding Roger Ward's family home is a rare site in this verdant swath of north-central Florida — most pines here are cut and processed for profit as soon as their 15-to-18-year growth cycle is complete.

headline: Charities, Large and Small, Give Migrants Critical Aid
paragraph: Charities and humanitarian organizations provide critical aid to waves of migrants arriving in Europe, hungry and exhausted, or sometimes ill, after long, treacherous journeys and still hoping to reach their chosen destination in the West. headline: In 911 Call, Professor Admits to Shooting Girlfriend
paragraph: In a 911 call, his voice only slightly shaky, college professor Shannon Lamb told police he had shot his girlfriend and officers needed to get over to their house. Lamb made a point to say his "sweet dog" was there alive and probably upset, and said the dead woman's family contacts could be found on her phone.

abstract: Op-Ed article by attorneys Thomas Moore and Steve Cohen laments fate of Lavern's Law, bill introduced in New York State Assembly that would have given victims of serious medical errors better chance at filing medical malpractice lawsuits and winning fair claims against negligent doctors and hospitals in court; contends there is shame in both fact that bill never made it to a vote in Albany, and that hospitals and doctors fought so hard to block legislation intended to protect the public.

headline: End to Brady Suspension a Game-Changer for NFL Fantasy Football

abstract: Sankuyo, Botswana, is one of several rural African communities calling for return to trophy hunting, practice banned two years ago to protect wild animals; says national ban leaves residents, crops and livestock prey to rising number of animal predators and has reduced their incomes, which were often supplemented by hunting parties; request comes as more African nations face pressure to ban trophy hunting, fueled by tragic death of research subject, Cecil the lion, in Zimbabwe.
headline: A Hunting Ban Saps a Village’s Livelihood

headline: Candy and Cuddly Toys: Migrants Finish Epic Trek to Germany
paragraph: For weeks while they traveled a punitive road, Europe cast a cold and callous eye on their unwelcome progress. On Saturday, for the first time since fleeing their troubled homelands, they could set foot in their promised land — and it came with a German face so friendly that it brought some newcomers to tears of joy.

abstract: Rui Hai International Logistics has become symbol of corruption in China in wake of chemical explosion in Tianjin that killed 150 people and left more than 700 wounded; interviews with former associates and clients of Rui Hai, along with Chinese state media accounts, reveal company that exploited political connections to avoid governmental oversight of shipping of hazardous chemicals; explosion has raised questions about cost to public health and safety presented by party officials pursuing development projects.
headline: Behind Deadly Tianjin Blast, Shortcuts and Lax Rules
paragraph: Rui Hai International Logistics, whose warehouses were hit by the deadly explosions, has become a symbol of the high cost of rapid industrialization in a closed political system rife with graft.
text: Behind Deadly Tianjin Blast, Shortcuts and Lax Rules Rui Hai International Logistics, whose warehouses were hit by the deadly explosions, has become a symbol of the high cost of rapid industrialization in a closed political system rife with graft. Rui Hai International Logistics has become symbol of corruption in China in wake of chemical explosion in Tianjin that killed 150 people and left more than 700 wounded; interviews with former associates and clients of Rui Hai, along with Chinese state media accounts, reveal company that exploited political connections to avoid governmental oversight of shipping of hazardous chemicals; explosion has raised questions about cost to public health and safety presented by party officials pursuing development projects.

headline: A Look at What Migrants Are Carrying With Them to Europe
paragraph: To survive days on end of walking and improvised camping in harsh weather, they must concentrate on essentials: pain medicine, foot powder and first aid, food and personal hygiene items. The savviest have smartphones with backup battery power and SIM cards that work in the countries they're passing through. Otherwise, they can end up walking in circles without satellite navigation, particularly at night, when many travel to avoid police.

abstract: Protest rally organized by Hardik Patel in Ahmedabad, India, to challenge country's quota system regarding caste stuns political elite, particularly those of Prime Min Narendra Modi's inner circle; more than 500,000 people attend rally, almost all of them members of caste whose support Modi has relied upon to triumph in elections; Patel has called for inclusion of his relatively affluent caste in quota system, which would effectively dismantle it.
headline: Caste Quotas in India Come Under Attack
paragraph: Resentment has gelled into opposition to India’s version of affirmative action, a system of strict quotas that reserves nearly half of jobs for those from disadvantaged castes or tribes.
text: Caste Quotas in India Come Under Attack Resentment has gelled into opposition to India’s version of affirmative action, a system of strict quotas that reserves nearly half of jobs for those from disadvantaged castes or tribes. Protest rally organized by Hardik Patel in Ahmedabad, India, to challenge country's quota system regarding caste stuns political elite, particularly those of Prime Min Narendra Modi's inner circle; more than 500,000 people attend rally, almost all of them members of caste whose support Modi has relied upon to triumph in elections; Patel has called for inclusion of his relatively affluent caste in quota system, which would effectively dismantle it.

headline: AP Exclusive: Drilling Boom Means More Harmful Waste Spills
paragraph: Carl Johnson and son Justin are third- and fourth-generation ranchers who for decades have battled oilfield companies that left a patchwork of barren earth where the men graze cattle in the high plains of New Mexico. Blunt and profane, they stroll across a 1 1/2-acre patch of sandy soil — lifeless, save for a scattering of stunted weeds.
text: AP Exclusive: Drilling Boom Means More Harmful Waste Spills Carl Johnson and son Justin are third- and fourth-generation ranchers who for decades have battled oilfield companies that left a patchwork of barren earth where the men graze cattle in the high plains of New Mexico. Blunt and profane, they stroll across a 1 1/2-acre patch of sandy soil — lifeless, save for a scattering of stunted weeds.

abstract: Vendors at conference of American Correctional Assn, essentially trade fair for products sold to prisons, ranging from plastic kitchen tools to clothing and riot gear, seem unperturbed by national movement toward sentencing reform; industry serves an immense population, with two publicly traded players alone boasting combined market capitalization of almost $5.8 billion; many are confident that sentencing reform will come slowly, and will not greatly reduce prison populations because focus is only on nonviolent offenders.
headline: Prison Vendors See Continued Signs of a Captive Market
paragraph: As judges and policy makers debate sentencing changes to curb incarceration, those who sell goods to jails and prisons find little cause for concern.
text: Prison Vendors See Continued Signs of a Captive Market As judges and policy makers debate sentencing changes to curb incarceration, those who sell goods to jails and prisons find little cause for concern. Vendors at conference of American Correctional Assn, essentially trade fair for products sold to prisons, ranging from plastic kitchen tools to clothing and riot gear, seem unperturbed by national movement toward sentencing reform; industry serves an immense population, with two publicly traded players alone boasting combined market capitalization of almost $5.8 billion; many are confident that sentencing reform will come slowly, and will not greatly reduce prison populations because focus is only on nonviolent offenders.

headline: Blatter's Corroded Legacy on South Asian Soccer Fields
paragraph: There are no recognizable soccer fields, no players, and just a rusting goalpost at Pakistan's Hawksbay training center, built with a $500,000 FIFA grant on a windswept plot by the Arabian Sea near Karachi, and officially completed two years ago.
text: Blatter's Corroded Legacy on South Asian Soccer Fields There are no recognizable soccer fields, no players, and just a rusting goalpost at Pakistan's Hawksbay training center, built with a $500,000 FIFA grant on a windswept plot by the Arabian Sea near Karachi, and officially completed two years ago.

abstract: Judge Phyllis Randolph Frye of Houston, who came out as transgender in 1976, has for decades been on vanguard of transgender civil rights movement; Frye is enthusiastic about rising mainstream awareness of nation's transgender community, but is well-versed in history of movement, emphasizing that gender identity issues did not suddenly materialize with the very public transition of Caitlyn Jenner.
headline: Once a Pariah, Now a Judge: The Early Transgender Journey of Phyllis Frye
paragraph: Decades before Caitlyn Jenner, Phyllis Frye was grappling with bias, scorn and personal pain, and helping the transgender movement take shape.
text: Once a Pariah, Now a Judge: The Early Transgender Journey of Phyllis Frye Decades before Caitlyn Jenner, Phyllis Frye was grappling with bias, scorn and personal pain, and helping the transgender movement take shape. Judge Phyllis Randolph Frye of Houston, who came out as transgender in 1976, has for decades been on vanguard of transgender civil rights movement; Frye is enthusiastic about rising mainstream awareness of nation's transgender community, but is well-versed in history of movement, emphasizing that gender identity issues did not suddenly materialize with the very public transition of Caitlyn Jenner.

abstract: Uber's luring of 40 scientists from Carnegie Mellon University's National Robotics Engineering Center has raised question of how universities can maintain talent when pitted against salaries offered by private tech companies; corporate world hungry for scientific talent is likely to affect robot research and learning.
headline: Uber Would Like to Buy Your Robotics Department
paragraph: When the company wanted a team of roboticists, it raided a university lab to get them. Can high-tech academia survive today’s Silicon Valley talent binge?
text: Uber Would Like to Buy Your Robotics Department When the company wanted a team of roboticists, it raided a university lab to get them. Can high-tech academia survive today’s Silicon Valley talent binge? Uber's luring of 40 scientists from Carnegie Mellon University's National Robotics Engineering Center has raised question of how universities can maintain talent when pitted against salaries offered by private tech companies; corporate world hungry for scientific talent is likely to affect robot research and learning.

abstract: Advances in sciences of brain preservation and brain mapping have given some people hope that their consciousness and personality could some day be recreated in computer after their death; many neuroscientists dismiss such speculation, saying very little is understood about workings of human brain; Kim Suozzi, who died of brain cancer in 2013 at age 23, had her head cryopreserved on off chance that she may some day be brought back in some capacity.
headline: A Dying Young Woman’s Hope in Cryonics and a Future
paragraph: Cancer claimed Kim Suozzi at age 23, but she chose to have her brain preserved with the dream that neuroscience might one day revive her mind.
text: A Dying Young Woman’s Hope in Cryonics and a Future Cancer claimed Kim Suozzi at age 23, but she chose to have her brain preserved with the dream that neuroscience might one day revive her mind. Advances in sciences of brain preservation and brain mapping have given some people hope that their consciousness and personality could some day be recreated in computer after their death; many neuroscientists dismiss such speculation, saying very little is understood about workings of human brain; Kim Suozzi, who died of brain cancer in 2013 at age 23, had her head cryopreserved on off chance that she may some day be brought back in some capacity.
